name: Scientific Methods and Measurement
short_description: Introduction to scientific inquiry, experimental design, measurement systems, significant figures, and uncertainty analysis. Students develop skills in making observations, forming hypotheses, conducting experiments, and analyzing data with appropriate precision.

sub_topics.name: Scientific Inquiry Process
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the steps of scientific investigation including observation, hypothesis formation, experimentation, and conclusion drawing.

sub_topics.name: Making Observations and Inferences
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between qualitative and quantitative observations and drawing logical inferences from data.
example_tasks: Observe a pendulum swinging and record three qualitative observations (e.g., color, shape) and three quantitative observations (e.g., length, swing time).
Watch a demonstration of objects falling and infer which factors might affect the rate of fall based on your observations.
Examine data showing ice melting at different temperatures and infer the relationship between temperature and melting rate.

sub_topics.name: Forming Testable Hypotheses
sub_topics.short_description: Creating hypotheses that can be tested through experimentation and distinguishing between testable and non-testable statements.
example_tasks: Write a testable hypothesis about how the angle of a ramp affects the speed of a cart rolling down it.
Evaluate whether the statement 'Heavy objects fall faster than light objects' is a testable hypothesis and explain why.
Given the observation that a ball bounces higher on some surfaces than others, formulate a hypothesis about the relationship between surface type and bounce height.

sub_topics.name: Experimental Design and Variables
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying independent, dependent, and controlled variables while designing fair and valid experiments.
example_tasks: Design an experiment to test how the mass of a pendulum bob affects its period, identifying all variables that must be controlled.
Analyze a given experiment about plant growth and identify the independent variable, dependent variable, and at least three controlled variables.
Critique an experimental setup for testing battery life and suggest improvements to make it a fair test.

sub_topics.name: Data Collection and Recording
sub_topics.short_description: Developing proper techniques for collecting, organizing, and recording experimental data in tables and charts.
example_tasks: Create a data table with appropriate headers to record the position of a moving cart at 1-second intervals over 10 seconds.
Conduct an experiment measuring the temperature of water every minute as it heats and record data in an organized table with units.
Design a data collection sheet for an experiment investigating how spring stretch depends on hanging mass, including columns for trials and averages.

sub_topics.name: Measurement Systems and Units
sub_topics.short_description: Working with the International System of Units (SI), metric prefixes, and performing unit conversions accurately.

sub_topics.name: SI Base and Derived Units
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the seven SI base units and how derived units are formed from combinations of base units.
example_tasks: Identify the SI base units for length, mass, time, and temperature, and give an example measurement using each.
Explain why velocity is measured in m/s and show how this unit is derived from base units.
Determine the SI units for density by analyzing the formula density = mass/volume and expressing your answer in base units.

sub_topics.name: Metric Prefixes and Conversions
sub_topics.short_description: Using metric prefixes (kilo-, centi-, milli-, micro-, nano-) and converting between different metric units.
example_tasks: Convert 2.5 kilometers to meters and then to centimeters, showing all steps in your work.
Express 0.000045 seconds using an appropriate metric prefix (e.g., microseconds) and explain your choice.
A student measures a wire as 3.2 cm thick. Convert this measurement to millimeters, meters, and micrometers.

sub_topics.name: Unit Conversion and Dimensional Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Applying dimensional analysis techniques to convert between different unit systems and check equation validity.
example_tasks: Convert a speed of 60 miles per hour to meters per second using dimensional analysis (1 mile = 1609 meters).
Use dimensional analysis to verify that the equation distance = speed × time is dimensionally consistent.
Convert a density of 8.9 g/cm³ to kg/m³ by setting up and solving conversion factors systematically.

sub_topics.name: Precision, Accuracy, and Uncertainty
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between precision and accuracy, estimating measurement uncertainty, and understanding the limitations of measuring instruments.

sub_topics.name: Accuracy vs. Precision
sub_topics.short_description: Differentiating between how close measurements are to the true value (accuracy) and how close they are to each other (precision).
example_tasks: Given four student measurements of a 10.0 cm object (9.8 cm, 9.9 cm, 10.1 cm, 9.9 cm), determine if the data is accurate and precise, explaining your reasoning.
Draw a target diagram showing four different scenarios: high accuracy and high precision, high accuracy and low precision, low accuracy and high precision, and low accuracy and low precision.
A thermometer consistently reads 3°C higher than the actual temperature. Describe whether this thermometer has an accuracy or precision problem.

sub_topics.name: Measurement Uncertainty
sub_topics.short_description: Estimating and expressing uncertainty in measurements based on instrument precision and measurement techniques.
example_tasks: Measure the length of a pencil using a ruler marked in millimeters and express your answer with appropriate uncertainty (e.g., 15.4 ± 0.1 cm).
A digital scale reads 245.3 g. Determine the uncertainty of this measurement and express the mass as a range.
Compare the uncertainty when measuring 50 mL of water with a graduated cylinder (marked every 1 mL) versus a beaker (marked every 25 mL).

sub_topics.name: Significant Figures Rules
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying significant figures in measurements and applying rules for calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.
example_tasks: Determine the number of significant figures in each measurement: 0.00450 m, 3.20 × 10⁴ kg, 100 s, and 5.070 N.
Calculate the area of a rectangle with length 12.4 cm and width 3.2 cm, expressing your answer with the correct number of significant figures.
Add the following masses and round to the correct precision: 45.3 g + 2.15 g + 0.008 g.

sub_topics.name: Percent Error Calculations
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating percent error to quantify the difference between experimental and accepted values.
example_tasks: A student measures the acceleration due to gravity as 10.2 m/s². Calculate the percent error if the accepted value is 9.8 m/s².
In an experiment, the measured density of aluminum is 2.65 g/cm³ while the accepted value is 2.70 g/cm³. Find the percent error and discuss possible sources of error.
Determine which measurement is more accurate: Student A measures a 50.0 g mass as 48.5 g, or Student B measures a 200.0 g mass as 195.0 g. Support your answer with percent error calculations.

sub_topics.name: Graphing and Data Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Creating appropriate graphs from data, identifying relationships between variables, and interpreting graphical information in physics contexts.

sub_topics.name: Creating Proper Graphs
sub_topics.short_description: Constructing graphs with proper scales, labels, titles, and appropriate choice of graph type for the data.
example_tasks: Given data showing the position of a car at different times, create a position vs. time graph with properly labeled axes, appropriate scale, and a descriptive title.
Plot the following data points showing mass vs. volume for a substance: (10g, 5mL), (20g, 10mL), (30g, 15mL), (40g, 20mL). Include a line of best fit.
Create a bar graph comparing the average bounce heights of three different types of balls, including error bars to show uncertainty.

sub_topics.name: Interpreting Linear Relationships
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing linear graphs to determine slope, y-intercept, and the physical meaning of these values.
example_tasks: From a distance vs. time graph with a straight line passing through (0s, 0m) and (10s, 50m), calculate the slope and explain what it represents physically.
A force vs. acceleration graph for a cart yields a slope of 2.5 kg. Explain what this value represents and identify the physical quantity.
Given a velocity vs. time graph with equation v = 3t + 5, identify the initial velocity and the acceleration of the object.

sub_topics.name: Curve Linearization
sub_topics.short_description: Converting non-linear relationships into linear form by plotting appropriate variables to determine relationships.
example_tasks: Given data suggesting period² is proportional to length for a pendulum, explain how you would plot the data to produce a straight line and what the slope would represent.
If force and spring stretch are related by F = kx, describe how to create a graph that would allow you to determine the spring constant k from the slope.
Distance fallen by a dropped object follows d = ½gt². Explain what variables you would plot to get a linear graph and how to extract the acceleration g from it.

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Graph Shapes
sub_topics.short_description: Interpreting the physical meaning of different graph shapes including positive/negative slopes, curves, and area under curves.
example_tasks: Sketch and describe position vs. time graphs for: an object at rest, an object moving at constant velocity, and an object accelerating.
Given a velocity vs. time graph, explain how to determine the object's displacement and identify regions where the object is speeding up or slowing down.
Compare the motion of two objects whose velocity vs. time graphs are parallel lines with different y-intercepts. What is similar and what is different about their motion?

name: Motion in One Dimension
short_description: Study of kinematics including position, displacement, velocity, acceleration, and motion with constant acceleration. Students learn to describe and analyze motion using equations, graphs, and problem-solving strategies.

sub_topics.name: Position and Displacement
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding position as location relative to a reference point and displacement as change in position, including vector nature and sign conventions.

sub_topics.name: Reference Frames and Coordinate Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Establishing reference points and coordinate systems to describe position and motion in one dimension.
example_tasks: Choose an appropriate reference point and coordinate system to describe a car's position traveling along a straight highway. Explain your choice.
A student walks 5 m east from the classroom door, then 3 m west. Using the door as the origin, determine the student's final position.
Describe how the position of a ball thrown vertically upward changes over time, specifying a positive direction and reference point.

sub_topics.name: Calculating Displacement
sub_topics.short_description: Computing displacement as the change in position and understanding the difference between distance traveled and displacement.
example_tasks: A runner starts at position x = 10 m and finishes at position x = 60 m. Calculate the displacement.
A car travels 40 km north, then 30 km south. Calculate both the total distance traveled and the displacement.
From a position vs. time graph, determine the displacement of an object between t = 2 s and t = 7 s if the positions are 5 m and 25 m respectively.

sub_topics.name: Vector Nature of Displacement
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing displacement as a vector quantity with both magnitude and direction, and using positive and negative signs to indicate direction.
example_tasks: Explain why a displacement of -15 m is different from a distance of 15 m, giving a specific example.
Two students have displacements of +20 m and -20 m respectively. Describe possible scenarios for how each student moved.
A bird flies back and forth along a wire. If it starts at position 0 m and ends at position 0 m, explain why the displacement is zero even though it flew a considerable distance.

sub_topics.name: Velocity and Speed
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between average and instantaneous velocity, understanding speed as the magnitude of velocity, and interpreting velocity from position-time graphs.

sub_topics.name: Average Velocity
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating average velocity as displacement divided by time interval and interpreting its meaning.
example_tasks: A cyclist travels from position 100 m to position 400 m in 20 seconds. Calculate the average velocity.
During a 5-second interval, a car's position changes from x = 30 m to x = 10 m. Find the average velocity and explain the meaning of its sign.
A jogger runs 200 m east in 40 s, then 100 m west in 25 s. Calculate the average velocity for the entire trip.

sub_topics.name: Instantaneous Velocity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding instantaneous velocity as the velocity at a specific moment and determining it from the slope of position-time graphs.
example_tasks: From a position vs. time graph, determine the instantaneous velocity at t = 3 s by calculating the slope of the tangent line at that point.
Explain the difference between average velocity over a 10-second interval and instantaneous velocity at the 5-second mark.
A position-time graph shows a curve that gets steeper over time. Describe how the instantaneous velocity changes and explain what this means about the object's motion.

sub_topics.name: Speed vs. Velocity
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between speed (scalar) and velocity (vector) and understanding when they have the same or different values.
example_tasks: A car travels around a circular track at constant speed. Explain whether its velocity is also constant.
Calculate both the average speed and average velocity for a person who walks 30 m east, then 30 m west, taking 2 minutes total.
An object has a velocity of -15 m/s. What is its speed? Explain the difference between these two values.

sub_topics.name: Velocity from Graphs
sub_topics.short_description: Determining velocity by calculating slopes on position-time graphs and interpreting the physical meaning of positive, negative, and zero slopes.
example_tasks: From a position vs. time graph showing a straight line from (0s, 10m) to (8s, 50m), calculate the velocity.
Sketch a position vs. time graph for an object moving at -5 m/s for 6 seconds, starting at position +20 m.
Given a position-time graph with three distinct sections of different slopes, describe the velocity during each section and identify where the object is moving fastest.

sub_topics.name: Acceleration
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding acceleration as the rate of change of velocity, including average and instantaneous acceleration, and interpreting motion from velocity-time graphs.

sub_topics.name: Average Acceleration
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating average acceleration as change in velocity divided by time interval and understanding its units and meaning.
example_tasks: A car's velocity increases from 10 m/s to 30 m/s in 4 seconds. Calculate the average acceleration.
A ball rolling up a ramp slows from 8 m/s to 2 m/s in 3 seconds. Find the average acceleration and explain why it is negative.
During braking, a bicycle's velocity changes from +12 m/s to 0 m/s in 2.5 seconds. Calculate the average acceleration and describe the motion.

sub_topics.name: Instantaneous Acceleration
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding instantaneous acceleration and determining it from the slope of velocity-time graphs.
example_tasks: From a velocity vs. time graph with a constant slope of 3 m/s², determine the instantaneous acceleration at any time and explain why it's constant.
Explain the difference between the average acceleration over a 10-second interval and the instantaneous acceleration at t = 5 s.
A velocity-time graph shows a curve. Describe how to determine the instantaneous acceleration at t = 4 s.

sub_topics.name: Positive and Negative Acceleration
sub_topics.short_description: Interpreting the meaning of positive and negative acceleration and understanding that negative acceleration does not always mean slowing down.
example_tasks: An object has velocity +10 m/s and acceleration -2 m/s². Describe whether it is speeding up or slowing down and explain your reasoning.
An object has velocity -5 m/s and acceleration -3 m/s². Is it speeding up or slowing down? Justify your answer.

Sketch velocity vs. time graphs for four scenarios: speeding up with positive acceleration, slowing down with negative acceleration, speeding up with negative acceleration, and slowing down with positive acceleration.

sub_topics.name: Acceleration from Graphs
sub_topics.short_description: Determining acceleration from velocity-time graphs by calculating slopes and finding displacement from the area under velocity-time curves.
example_tasks: From a velocity vs. time graph showing a straight line from (0s, 5m/s) to (10s, 25m/s), calculate the acceleration.
Given a velocity-time graph, find the displacement of an object by calculating the area under the curve between t = 0 s and t = 6 s.
Sketch an acceleration vs. time graph corresponding to a velocity-time graph that shows constant positive slope, then zero slope, then constant negative slope.

sub_topics.name: Kinematic Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Applying the four kinematic equations to solve problems involving motion with constant acceleration, including free fall scenarios.

sub_topics.name: Four Kinematic Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Learning and applying the equations v = v₀ + at, Δx = v₀t + ½at², v² = v₀² + 2aΔx, and Δx = ½(v₀ + v)t for constant acceleration.
example_tasks: A car accelerates from rest at 3 m/s² for 5 seconds. Use v = v₀ + at to calculate its final velocity.
A ball rolls with initial velocity 8 m/s and acceleration -2 m/s². Use v² = v₀² + 2aΔx to find how far it travels before stopping.
An object starts with velocity 12 m/s and acceleration -4 m/s². How far does it travel in 3 seconds? Use Δx = v₀t + ½at².

sub_topics.name: Choosing the Appropriate Equation
sub_topics.short_description: Selecting the correct kinematic equation based on which variables are known and which are unknown in a problem.
example_tasks: Given initial velocity, final velocity, and time, identify which kinematic equation would best help you find acceleration.
You know initial velocity, acceleration, and displacement, but not time. Which kinematic equation should you use to find final velocity?
Create a decision chart showing which kinematic equation to use based on different combinations of known and unknown variables.

sub_topics.name: Multi-Step Kinematics Problems
sub_topics.short_description: Solving complex problems that require using multiple kinematic equations or breaking motion into distinct phases.
example_tasks: A car accelerates from rest at 2 m/s² for 10 seconds, then maintains constant velocity for 20 seconds. Find the total displacement.
A ball is thrown upward with initial velocity 20 m/s. Calculate (a) how high it goes, (b) how long until it reaches maximum height, and (c) its velocity when it returns to the starting height.
A motorcycle accelerates from 5 m/s to 25 m/s over 80 m. Find (a) the acceleration and (b) the time required.

sub_topics.name: Free Fall Motion
sub_topics.short_description: Applying kinematic equations to objects in free fall near Earth's surface with acceleration g = 9.8 m/s² downward.
example_tasks: A stone is dropped from rest from a cliff. How far does it fall in 3 seconds? (Use g = 9.8 m/s²)
A ball is thrown straight down with initial velocity 5 m/s from a height of 50 m. How long does it take to reach the ground?
An object is thrown vertically upward with initial velocity 30 m/s. Calculate its maximum height and the total time it stays in the air.

sub_topics.name: Graphical Kinematic Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Connecting kinematic equations to position-time, velocity-time, and acceleration-time graphs for complete motion analysis.
example_tasks: Sketch position, velocity, and acceleration vs. time graphs for an object starting from rest and accelerating uniformly for 5 seconds.
Given a velocity-time graph showing constant acceleration from 0 to 20 m/s over 4 seconds, use the graph to find both the acceleration and the displacement.
From an acceleration vs. time graph showing constant acceleration of 5 m/s² for 6 seconds, construct the corresponding velocity-time graph assuming the object started from rest.

name: Motion in Two Dimensions
short_description: Extension of kinematics to two-dimensional motion including vector components, projectile motion, circular motion, and relative velocity. Students learn to analyze motion in both horizontal and vertical directions simultaneously.

sub_topics.name: Vectors and Components
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding vector quantities, breaking vectors into components, and performing vector addition using component methods.

sub_topics.name: Vector Representation
sub_topics.short_description: Representing vectors graphically with arrows showing magnitude and direction, and using proper notation for vectors.
example_tasks: Draw a vector representing a displacement of 50 m at 30° north of east. Label the magnitude and direction clearly.
Represent the following vectors on the same coordinate system: velocity of 10 m/s east, velocity of 8 m/s north, and velocity of 12 m/s at 45° south of west.
Explain the difference between the notation for a scalar (v) and a vector (v⃗ or **v**) and give two examples of each type of quantity.

sub_topics.name: Resolving Vectors into Components
sub_topics.short_description: Breaking vectors into perpendicular x and y components using trigonometry (sine and cosine functions).
example_tasks: A force of 100 N is applied at an angle of 37° above the horizontal. Calculate the horizontal and vertical components of this force.
A velocity vector has magnitude 25 m/s at 60° from the positive x-axis. Determine the x-component and y-component of the velocity.
An airplane flies with airspeed 200 km/h at a heading of 120° (measured clockwise from north). Find the north-south and east-west components of the plane's velocity.

sub_topics.name: Vector Addition Using Components
sub_topics.short_description: Adding vectors by summing their components separately and finding the resultant magnitude and direction.
example_tasks: Add two displacement vectors: A⃗ = 40 m at 0° and B⃗ = 30 m at 90°. Find the magnitude and direction of the resultant.
A person walks 50 m north, then 120 m east. Use components to find the total displacement and the direction from the starting point.
Three forces act on an object: F₁ = 10 N at 0°, F₂ = 15 N at 90°, and F₃ = 8 N at 180°. Find the net force (magnitude and direction).

sub_topics.name: Finding Magnitude and Direction from Components
sub_topics.short_description: Using the Pythagorean theorem and inverse tangent to find magnitude and direction from x and y components.
example_tasks: A velocity has components vₓ = 12 m/s and vᵧ = 5 m/s. Calculate the magnitude and direction of the velocity vector.
The resultant of several forces has components Fₓ = -30 N and Fᵧ = 40 N. Find the magnitude and direction (measured from the positive x-axis).
An object's displacement has components Δx = -60 m and Δy = -80 m. Determine the total displacement magnitude and direction.

sub_topics.name: Projectile Motion
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the motion of projectiles launched at various angles, treating horizontal and vertical motion independently.

sub_topics.name: Horizontal and Vertical Independence
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that horizontal and vertical motions are independent and can be analyzed separately in projectile motion.
example_tasks: Explain why the horizontal velocity of a projectile remains constant while the vertical velocity changes during flight (neglecting air resistance).
A ball is thrown horizontally from a cliff. Describe the horizontal and vertical accelerations throughout the flight.
Two balls are released simultaneously: one is dropped vertically, the other is thrown horizontally. Explain why they hit the ground at the same time.

sub_topics.name: Horizontal Projectiles
sub_topics.short_description: Solving problems for objects launched horizontally from a height, analyzing time of flight, range, and impact velocity.
example_tasks: A ball rolls off a 20 m high table with horizontal velocity 5 m/s. Calculate (a) the time to hit the ground and (b) the horizontal distance traveled.
A package is dropped from an airplane flying horizontally at 100 m/s at an altitude of 500 m. How far horizontally does the package travel before hitting the ground?
A marble rolls off a desk 1.2 m high and lands 0.8 m from the base of the desk. Calculate the marble's initial horizontal velocity.

sub_topics.name: Projectiles Launched at Angles
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing projectile motion when launched at angles, finding maximum height, range, and time of flight.
example_tasks: A ball is kicked at 20 m/s at an angle of 30° above horizontal. Find (a) the initial horizontal and vertical velocity components, (b) the maximum height, and (c) the range.
A projectile is launched at 45° with initial speed 40 m/s. Calculate the total time of flight assuming it lands at the same height from which it was launched.
Determine the launch angle required for a projectile to achieve maximum range if launched with speed 25 m/s. Explain your reasoning.

sub_topics.name: Projectile Trajectory Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the parabolic path of projectiles and solving for position and velocity at any point during flight.
example_tasks: Sketch the trajectory of a projectile launched at 60° and show velocity vectors at launch, maximum height, and impact. Indicate how the vectors change.
A football is kicked at 18 m/s at 35° above horizontal. Find its position (x and y coordinates) and velocity (magnitude and direction) after 1.5 seconds.
Explain why the angle of projection that gives maximum range is 45° (neglecting air resistance) and what happens at steeper or shallower angles.

sub_topics.name: Circular Motion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding uniform circular motion, centripetal acceleration, period, frequency, and the relationship between linear and angular quantities.

sub_topics.name: Uniform Circular Motion Concepts
sub_topics.short_description: Defining uniform circular motion and understanding that velocity direction constantly changes even when speed is constant.
example_tasks: Explain why an object moving in a circle at constant speed is accelerating even though its speed doesn't change.
Sketch the velocity vectors for an object at four equally spaced points around a circular path. Indicate the direction of acceleration at each point.
A car travels around a circular track at constant speed. Describe what happens to its velocity vector and explain the term 'uniform circular motion'.

sub_topics.name: Centripetal Acceleration
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating centripetal acceleration using a = v²/r and understanding that it always points toward the center of the circle.
example_tasks: A car travels around a curve with radius 50 m at a speed of 20 m/s. Calculate the centripetal acceleration.
An object moves in a circle of radius 2 m with centripetal acceleration 8 m/s². Determine its speed.
Compare the centripetal acceleration of two runners on a track: one running at 5 m/s on the inside lane (radius 30 m) and another running at 6 m/s on the outside lane (radius 35 m).

sub_topics.name: Period and Frequency
sub_topics.short_description: Defining period (T) as time for one revolution and frequency (f) as revolutions per second, understanding that f = 1/T.
example_tasks: A satellite orbits Earth once every 90 minutes. Calculate its frequency in revolutions per second (Hz).
A wheel rotates with frequency 5 Hz. Determine (a) the period and (b) the number of revolutions in 1 minute.
The second hand of a clock has a period of 60 seconds. Calculate its frequency and explain the relationship between period and frequency.

sub_topics.name: Relating Linear and Angular Quantities
sub_topics.short_description: Connecting linear speed to angular speed using v = 2πr/T and understanding how position on a rotating object affects linear speed.
example_tasks: A merry-go-round with radius 3 m completes one revolution every 8 seconds. Calculate the linear speed of a child sitting at the edge.
Two children sit on a rotating platform: one at radius 1 m and another at radius 2 m. If the platform rotates with period 4 s, compare their linear speeds.
A car tire has radius 0.3 m and rotates at 10 revolutions per second. Calculate the linear speed of a point on the tire's edge.

sub_topics.name: Relative Velocity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how velocity depends on the frame of reference and calculating velocities of objects as observed from different reference frames.

sub_topics.name: Frames of Reference
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that motion is relative and depends on the observer's frame of reference.
example_tasks: Describe the motion of a ball dropped by a passenger on a moving train from the perspective of (a) the passenger and (b) someone standing on the platform.
You are riding in a car at 60 km/h. Another car passes you going 80 km/h in the same direction. What is the other car's velocity relative to you?
Explain why a person walking forward in a moving airplane has different velocities when measured relative to the plane versus relative to the ground.

sub_topics.name: Relative Velocity in One Dimension
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating relative velocities when objects move along the same line using vector addition and subtraction.
example_tasks: Car A travels east at 25 m/s and car B travels east at 15 m/s. Calculate the velocity of car A relative to car B.
A boat moves downstream at 12 m/s relative to the shore while the river current is 3 m/s. Find the boat's velocity relative to the water.
Two trains travel toward each other on parallel tracks. Train A moves at 30 m/s east and train B moves at 25 m/s west. Calculate the velocity of train A as observed from train B.

sub_topics.name: Relative Velocity in Two Dimensions
sub_topics.short_description: Solving relative velocity problems in two dimensions using vector addition of velocities.
example_tasks: A swimmer can swim at 2 m/s in still water. She swims directly across a river with current 1.5 m/s. Find her velocity relative to the shore (magnitude and direction).
An airplane has an airspeed of 200 km/h heading north. A wind blows at 50 km/h from the west. Calculate the plane's velocity relative to the ground.

A boat must cross a river that is 100 m wide with current 2 m/s. The boat can move at 5 m/s relative to the water. If the boat aims straight across, (a) what is its velocity relative to shore, and (b) where does it land?

name: Forces and Newton's Laws
short_description: Fundamental principles of dynamics including Newton's three laws of motion, force types, free-body diagrams, and applying Newton's second law to various situations. Students learn to analyze and predict object motion based on forces.

sub_topics.name: Force Concepts
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding force as a vector quantity, identifying different types of forces, and recognizing contact versus field forces.

sub_topics.name: Defining Force
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding force as a push or pull that can cause acceleration, measured in newtons (N), and recognizing force as a vector.
example_tasks: List five different forces acting on a book resting on a table and identify each as either a contact force or a field force.
Explain why force is a vector quantity and give an example showing how the direction of a force affects motion.
Convert a force of 50 N to kilograms times meters per second squared (kg⋅m/s²) and explain why these units are equivalent.

sub_topics.name: Types of Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying common forces including gravitational, normal, tension, friction, applied, and spring forces.
example_tasks: Draw and label all forces acting on a block being pulled by a rope across a horizontal surface with friction.
Explain the difference between weight (gravitational force) and normal force, giving a specific example where they are not equal.
Describe the direction of the tension force in a rope and explain why the tension is the same throughout an ideal massless rope.

sub_topics.name: Contact vs. Field Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between forces that require physical contact and forces that act at a distance through fields.
example_tasks: Categorize the following forces as contact or field forces: friction, gravity, normal force, magnetic force, tension, electric force.
Explain how gravity can affect an object without touching it, comparing it to a contact force like friction.
A book sits on a table. Identify all contact forces and all field forces acting on the book.

sub_topics.name: Free-Body Diagrams
sub_topics.short_description: Creating and using free-body diagrams to represent all forces acting on a single object, essential for applying Newton's laws.

sub_topics.name: Drawing Free-Body Diagrams
sub_topics.short_description: Representing an object as a point and drawing all force vectors acting on that object with proper labels and directions.
example_tasks: Draw a free-body diagram for a book resting on a table, showing and labeling all forces.
Create a free-body diagram for a sled being pulled up a frictionless inclined plane by a rope parallel to the slope.
Draw a free-body diagram for a ball hanging from a string attached to the ceiling, clearly labeling the tension and weight.

sub_topics.name: Forces on Inclined Planes
sub_topics.short_description: Creating free-body diagrams for objects on inclined surfaces and resolving weight into components parallel and perpendicular to the surface.
example_tasks: Draw a free-body diagram for a block on a 30° incline. Resolve the weight into components parallel and perpendicular to the incline.
A 10 kg box rests on a ramp inclined at 25°. Calculate the components of the weight parallel to and perpendicular to the ramp surface.
Explain why the normal force on an inclined plane is less than the object's weight, using a free-body diagram to support your explanation.

sub_topics.name: Multiple Object Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Drawing separate free-body diagrams for each object in a system and identifying action-reaction force pairs.
example_tasks: Two blocks (A and B) are connected by a rope, with block A being pulled to the right. Draw separate free-body diagrams for each block.
A person stands in an elevator. Draw free-body diagrams for both the person and the elevator car.
Two books are stacked on a table. Draw three separate free-body diagrams: one for the top book, one for the bottom book, and one for the table.

sub_topics.name: Newton's First Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the law of inertia: an object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion at constant velocity unless acted upon by a net force.

sub_topics.name: Law of Inertia
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that objects resist changes in their state of motion and that inertia depends on mass.
example_tasks: Explain using Newton's first law why passengers lurch forward when a car suddenly stops.
Give three real-world examples of inertia and explain how each demonstrates Newton's first law.
Why does a tablecloth can be pulled out from under dishes without disturbing them if done quickly? Explain using the concept of inertia.

sub_topics.name: Equilibrium Conditions
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing that when an object is in equilibrium (at rest or constant velocity), the net force is zero.
example_tasks: A book sits at rest on a table. Use Newton's first law to explain why the upward normal force must equal the downward gravitational force.
A car travels at constant velocity of 20 m/s on a straight road. What can you conclude about the net force on the car?
Three forces act on an object in equilibrium: F₁ = 10 N east, F₂ = 6 N north, and F₃ is unknown. Find the magnitude and direction of F₃.

sub_topics.name: Inertial Reference Frames
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that Newton's first law is valid in inertial (non-accelerating) reference frames.
example_tasks: Explain why a ball rolling on the floor of an accelerating car appears to roll backward from the perspective of a passenger.
Compare observing a falling object from a stationary platform versus from an elevator accelerating upward. In which frame does Newton's first law apply directly?
Describe what happens to a hanging air freshener in a car when the car accelerates forward. Explain from both the car's reference frame and an outside observer's frame.

sub_topics.name: Newton's Second Law
sub_topics.short_description: Applying F_net = ma to relate net force, mass, and acceleration, and solving problems involving multiple forces and objects.

sub_topics.name: F_net = ma
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding and applying the relationship between net force, mass, and acceleration in problem-solving.
example_tasks: A 5 kg box experiences a net force of 20 N. Calculate its acceleration.
What net force is required to accelerate a 1200 kg car from rest to 25 m/s in 10 seconds?
A 2 kg object experiences three forces: 10 N right, 6 N left, and 8 N right. Calculate the net force and the object's acceleration.

sub_topics.name: Component Form of Second Law
sub_topics.short_description: Applying Newton's second law separately in x and y directions: ΣFₓ = maₓ and ΣFᵧ = maᵧ.
example_tasks: A 3 kg block on a frictionless surface is pushed by forces of 12 N east and 5 N north. Find the magnitude and direction of the acceleration.
An object experiences forces Fₓ = 8 N and Fᵧ = -6 N with acceleration components aₓ = 4 m/s² and aᵧ = -3 m/s². Determine the object's mass.
A sled on a frictionless 30° incline has mass 10 kg. Using components parallel and perpendicular to the incline, find the acceleration down the slope.

sub_topics.name: Problems with Friction
sub_topics.short_description: Solving dynamics problems that include friction forces, using appropriate friction coefficients and normal forces.
example_tasks: A 20 kg box is pulled with a force of 100 N on a surface with coefficient of kinetic friction 0.3. Calculate the acceleration.
A 5 kg block experiences a 30 N applied force but doesn't move. If the coefficient of static friction is 0.7, explain why and calculate the maximum static friction force.
A car with mass 1500 kg brakes on a road where μₖ = 0.6. Find (a) the maximum deceleration and (b) the minimum stopping distance from 30 m/s.

sub_topics.name: Connected Objects
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing systems of connected objects using free-body diagrams and Newton's second law for each object.
example_tasks: Two blocks (m₁ = 3 kg, m₂ = 5 kg) are connected by a rope. A 40 N force pulls m₂. Assuming frictionless surfaces, find (a) the system acceleration and (b) the tension in the rope.
A 10 kg block sits on a table connected by a rope over a pulley to a 5 kg hanging block. Find the acceleration of the system and the tension in the rope (ignore friction and pulley mass).
Two blocks (4 kg and 6 kg) are pushed together on a frictionless surface by a 50 N force on the 4 kg block. Find the force the 4 kg block exerts on the 6 kg block.

sub_topics.name: Newton's Third Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding action-reaction force pairs: for every action force, there is an equal and opposite reaction force on a different object.

sub_topics.name: Action-Reaction Pairs
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying action-reaction force pairs that act on different objects, are equal in magnitude, and opposite in direction.
example_tasks: When you push on a wall, the wall pushes back on you. Identify the action and reaction forces and explain why you move but the wall doesn't.
A book rests on a table. Identify the action-reaction pair involving the book's weight and explain why the normal force is NOT the reaction to weight.
Identify all action-reaction pairs when a person walks forward on the ground.

sub_topics.name: Common Misconceptions
sub_topics.short_description: Clarifying that action-reaction pairs act on different objects and do not cancel each other out.
example_tasks: Explain why action-reaction pairs don't cancel each other out even though they are equal and opposite.
A horse pulls a cart. Some argue that the cart pulls back equally on the horse (Newton's third law), so they shouldn't move. Explain the flaw in this reasoning.
Distinguish between balanced forces that cancel (causing equilibrium) and action-reaction pairs that act on different objects.

sub_topics.name: Applications of Third Law
sub_topics.short_description: Applying Newton's third law to explain propulsion, recoil, and other phenomena in everyday situations.
example_tasks: Explain how a rocket moves in space where there is no air to push against, using Newton's third law.
A person jumps off a boat onto a dock. Use Newton's third law to explain what happens to the boat.

When a gun is fired, the bullet goes forward and the gun recoils backward. If the bullet has mass 0.01 kg and the gun has mass 2 kg, and the bullet leaves at 400 m/s, calculate the recoil velocity of the gun.

sub_topics.name: Friction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding static and kinetic friction, calculating friction forces using normal force and friction coefficients, and analyzing motion with friction.

sub_topics.name: Static vs. Kinetic Friction
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between static friction (preventing motion) and kinetic friction (opposing motion), and understanding that static friction varies while kinetic is constant.
example_tasks: Explain why it's harder to start pushing a heavy box than to keep it moving once it's started.
A 10 kg box sits on a floor with μₛ = 0.5 and μₖ = 0.3. Calculate (a) the maximum static friction force and (b) the kinetic friction force when moving.
Graph the friction force vs. applied force for a stationary object, showing the transition from static to kinetic friction.

sub_topics.name: Calculating Friction Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Using f = μN to calculate friction forces and understanding the relationship between friction, normal force, and friction coefficient.
example_tasks: A 50 kg person stands on a floor where μₛ = 0.8. Calculate the maximum static friction force available.
A 15 kg sled slides down a slope with normal force 120 N. If μₖ = 0.2, calculate the kinetic friction force.
A 20 kg box is pulled horizontally with force 100 N on a surface where μₖ = 0.4. Calculate (a) the normal force, (b) the friction force, and (c) the net force.

sub_topics.name: Friction on Inclines
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing friction on inclined planes and determining whether objects slide or remain stationary.
example_tasks: A 5 kg block rests on a 30° incline with μₛ = 0.6. Determine whether the block will slide by comparing the component of weight down the slope to the maximum static friction.
A 8 kg box slides down a 25° ramp with μₖ = 0.3. Calculate the acceleration of the box.
Find the minimum coefficient of static friction needed to prevent a car from sliding on a 15° banked curve.

name: Work, Energy, and Power
short_description: Understanding work as force times displacement, various forms of energy, conservation of energy principle, and power as the rate of energy transfer. Students learn to solve problems using energy methods as an alternative to force analysis.

sub_topics.name: Work Done by Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating work using W = Fd cos θ and understanding when work is positive, negative, or zero based on force and displacement directions.

sub_topics.name: Definition of Work
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding work as the product of force and displacement in the direction of the force, measured in joules (J).
example_tasks: A person pushes a box with a force of 50 N over a distance of 10 m. Calculate the work done if the force is applied horizontally.
Explain why holding a heavy box stationary above your head does no work in the physics sense, even though it requires effort.
Convert 500 J of work to newton-meters and explain why these units are equivalent.

sub_topics.name: Work with Angles
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating work when force is applied at an angle to displacement using W = Fd cos θ.
example_tasks: A child pulls a wagon with a force of 30 N at an angle of 40° above horizontal for a distance of 20 m. Calculate the work done.
A lawn mower is pushed with a force of 80 N at 30° below the horizontal for 15 m. Find the work done by the pushing force.
Explain why the work done by a centripetal force on an object in circular motion is zero.

sub_topics.name: Positive, Negative, and Zero Work
sub_topics.short_description: Determining the sign of work based on whether force aids, opposes, or is perpendicular to motion.
example_tasks: A 5 kg box is lifted vertically 2 m at constant velocity. Calculate the work done by (a) the lifting force and (b) gravity.
A car brakes to a stop over 50 m with friction force 3000 N. Calculate the work done by friction and explain why it's negative.
Identify whether work is positive, negative, or zero for: (a) normal force on a sliding box, (b) tension in a pendulum, (c) air resistance on a falling object.

sub_topics.name: Net Work
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating the total work done by all forces (net work) by summing individual work values or using net force.
example_tasks: A 10 kg box is pulled 8 m by a 60 N force while friction does -200 J of work. Calculate the net work on the box.
Three forces act on an object moving 5 m horizontally: 40 N forward, 15 N backward, and 20 N upward. Calculate the net work.
A 2 kg object accelerates from rest to 10 m/s. If friction does -50 J of work, find the work done by the applied force.

sub_topics.name: Kinetic Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding kinetic energy as energy of motion, calculating it using KE = ½mv², and applying the work-energy theorem.

sub_topics.name: Kinetic Energy Calculation
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating kinetic energy using KE = ½mv² and understanding how it depends on mass and velocity.
example_tasks: Calculate the kinetic energy of a 1200 kg car traveling at 25 m/s.
A 0.5 kg ball moves at 10 m/s. If its speed doubles, by what factor does its kinetic energy increase?
Two objects have the same kinetic energy: a 2 kg object and a 4 kg object. Compare their speeds.

sub_topics.name: Work-Energy Theorem
sub_topics.short_description: Applying the work-energy theorem: net work equals change in kinetic energy (W_net = ΔKE).
example_tasks: A 5 kg object initially at rest experiences 100 J of net work. Find its final speed.
A car with mass 1000 kg slows from 30 m/s to 20 m/s. Calculate the net work done on the car.
A 2 kg box slides across a floor with initial speed 8 m/s and comes to rest after traveling 5 m. Use the work-energy theorem to find the friction force.

sub_topics.name: Applications of Work-Energy Theorem
sub_topics.short_description: Using the work-energy theorem to solve complex problems involving multiple forces and changing speeds.
example_tasks: A 50 kg sled starts from rest and slides down a frictionless 20 m hill. If it reaches the bottom with speed 15 m/s, find the height of the hill.
A 1500 kg car accelerates from 10 m/s to 25 m/s while traveling 100 m. Calculate the net force on the car using the work-energy theorem.
A 0.2 kg hockey puck sliding at 10 m/s experiences a friction force of 2 N. How far does it slide before stopping?

sub_topics.name: Potential Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding gravitational and elastic potential energy, calculating stored energy in systems, and recognizing energy transformations.

sub_topics.name: Gravitational Potential Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating gravitational potential energy using PE = mgh and understanding its dependence on height above a reference level.
example_tasks: Calculate the gravitational potential energy of a 5 kg object held 10 m above the ground (use g = 10 m/s²).
A 70 kg person climbs stairs to a height of 15 m. How much gravitational potential energy do they gain?
Explain why gravitational potential energy depends on the choice of reference level and give an example where different reference points would be useful.

sub_topics.name: Elastic Potential Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating elastic potential energy stored in springs using PE_elastic = ½kx² where k is the spring constant.
example_tasks: A spring with spring constant 200 N/m is compressed 0.5 m. Calculate the elastic potential energy stored.
How much would you need to stretch a spring with k = 100 N/m to store 50 J of elastic potential energy?
Compare the elastic potential energy when a spring is compressed 0.1 m versus 0.2 m. By what factor does the energy change?

sub_topics.name: Energy Transformations
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying transformations between kinetic energy, gravitational potential energy, and elastic potential energy in physical systems.
example_tasks: Describe the energy transformations that occur when a ball is thrown upward and falls back down, identifying when KE and PE are maximum and minimum.
A pendulum swings back and forth. Explain the energy transformations at the highest point, lowest point, and midway points of the swing.
A compressed spring launches a ball vertically upward. Describe the energy transformations from compression to maximum height.

sub_topics.name: Conservation of Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Applying the law of conservation of energy to solve problems in systems without friction, and understanding energy conservation with non-conservative forces.

sub_topics.name: Mechanical Energy Conservation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that mechanical energy (KE + PE) is conserved in the absence of friction and other non-conservative forces.
example_tasks: A 2 kg ball is dropped from a height of 20 m. Use conservation of energy to find its speed just before hitting the ground (ignore air resistance).
A roller coaster car with mass 500 kg has speed 10 m/s at the top of a 30 m hill. Find its speed at the bottom (neglect friction).
A pendulum bob is released from a height of 0.5 m above its lowest point. Calculate its speed at the lowest point using energy conservation.

sub_topics.name: Problem Solving with Energy Conservation
sub_topics.short_description: Setting up and solving problems using initial energy equals final energy (E_i = E_f) for conservative systems.
example_tasks: A 1 kg ball is thrown upward with initial speed 15 m/s from ground level. Use energy conservation to find its maximum height.
A 60 kg skier starts from rest at the top of a 50 m high slope. Assuming no friction, find the skier's speed at the bottom.
A spring with k = 400 N/m is compressed 0.3 m and used to launch a 0.5 kg ball horizontally. Find the ball's launch speed.

sub_topics.name: Energy with Friction
sub_topics.short_description: Accounting for energy dissipation due to friction and other non-conservative forces in energy conservation problems.
example_tasks: A 10 kg box slides down a 5 m high ramp and reaches the bottom with speed 8 m/s. Calculate the energy lost to friction.
A 2 kg block slides 4 m across a surface with coefficient of kinetic friction 0.3, starting with speed 10 m/s. Find its final speed using energy methods.
A pendulum is released from height 1 m. Due to air resistance, it only reaches 0.9 m on the other side. What percentage of mechanical energy was lost?

sub_topics.name: Energy Bar Charts
sub_topics.short_description: Using energy bar charts to visualize and track energy transformations in physical processes.
example_tasks: Create an energy bar chart showing KE, PE, and total energy for a ball at three points: when thrown upward, at maximum height, and when caught at the same level.
Draw energy bar charts for a compressed spring before release, during launch of a ball, and when the ball reaches maximum height.
Use an energy bar chart to show how mechanical energy decreases as a box slides to a stop due to friction.

sub_topics.name: Power
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding power as the rate of energy transfer or work done, calculating power using P = W/t or P = Fv, and comparing power outputs.

sub_topics.name: Defining Power
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding power as work per unit time or energy transfer per unit time, measured in watts (W) or joules per second.
example_tasks: A motor does 5000 J of work in 10 seconds. Calculate the power output.
Explain the difference between energy and power, using the example of two people climbing the same stairs at different speeds.
Convert a power of 2.5 kW to watts and to horsepower (1 hp = 746 W).

sub_topics.name: Calculating Power
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating power using P = W/t for work done over time or P = Fv for constant force at constant velocity.
example_tasks: A 60 kg person climbs a 10 m staircase in 20 seconds. Calculate their power output (use g = 10 m/s²).
A car engine exerts a forward force of 4000 N while cruising at constant velocity 25 m/s. Calculate the power output.
An elevator lifts a 500 kg load at constant speed 2 m/s. What power is required from the motor (neglecting friction)?

sub_topics.name: Power and Efficiency
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding efficiency as useful power output divided by total power input, and calculating efficiency percentages.
example_tasks: An electric motor requires 1200 W of electrical power and outputs 900 W of mechanical power. Calculate its efficiency.
A light bulb converts 100 W of electrical energy into 5 W of light and 95 W of heat. What is the efficiency for producing light?
A crane with 75% efficiency lifts a 1000 kg load 20 m in 50 seconds. Calculate (a) the useful power output and (b) the total power input required.

name: Momentum and Collisions
short_description: Understanding linear momentum as mass times velocity, impulse as change in momentum, conservation of momentum in isolated systems, and analyzing elastic and inelastic collisions. Students learn alternative methods for analyzing interactions.

sub_topics.name: Linear Momentum
sub_topics.short_description: Defining momentum as p = mv, understanding momentum as a vector quantity, and calculating momentum in various situations.

sub_topics.name: Calculating Momentum
sub_topics.short_description: Computing momentum using p = mv and understanding its units (kg·m/s) and vector nature.
example_tasks: Calculate the momentum of a 1500 kg car traveling at 20 m/s east.
A 0.5 kg ball moves with velocity -8 m/s (westward). Determine its momentum, including direction.
Compare the momenta of a 2000 kg truck moving at 15 m/s and a 1000 kg car moving at 30 m/s.

sub_topics.name: Momentum and Force
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Newton's second law in momentum form: F = Δp/Δt, relating force to rate of change of momentum.
example_tasks: A 0.2 kg baseball changes velocity from 20 m/s to -15 m/s (opposite direction) in 0.01 s. Calculate the average force exerted.
A 60 kg person accelerates from rest to 5 m/s in 2 seconds. Calculate the net force using the momentum form of Newton's second law.
Explain why catching a ball by pulling your hands back reduces the force on your hands, using the concept of momentum change over time.

sub_topics.name: System Momentum
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating total momentum of a system by vector addition of individual momenta.
example_tasks: Two objects move along the same line: a 3 kg object at +5 m/s and a 2 kg object at -4 m/s. Find the total momentum of the system.
Calculate the total momentum of a system with a 5 kg object moving east at 6 m/s and a 3 kg object moving north at 8 m/s.
Three particles have momenta: p₁ = 10 kg·m/s east, p₂ = 8 kg·m/s north, and p₃ = 6 kg·m/s west. Find the total system momentum.

sub_topics.name: Impulse
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding impulse as the change in momentum and as the product of force and time interval, and relating impulse to force-time graphs.

sub_topics.name: Impulse-Momentum Theorem
sub_topics.short_description: Applying the impulse-momentum theorem: impulse equals change in momentum (J = Δp = FΔt).
example_tasks: A 1 kg object's velocity changes from 5 m/s to 15 m/s. Calculate the impulse delivered to the object.
A 0.15 kg baseball is hit, changing its velocity from 25 m/s toward the pitcher to 30 m/s toward the outfield. Find the impulse.
A 60 kg skater initially at rest receives an impulse of 180 kg·m/s. Calculate their final velocity.

sub_topics.name: Calculating Impulse
sub_topics.short_description: Computing impulse using J = FΔt for constant forces or from force-time graphs for varying forces.
example_tasks: A constant force of 50 N acts on an object for 3 seconds. Calculate the impulse delivered.
A force-time graph shows a triangular pulse with maximum force 100 N lasting 0.5 s. Calculate the impulse by finding the area under the curve.
During a collision lasting 0.02 s, an average force of 500 N acts on a 2 kg object initially at rest. Find the object's final velocity.

sub_topics.name: Applications of Impulse
sub_topics.short_description: Applying impulse concepts to safety devices and understanding how extending collision time reduces force.
example_tasks: Explain why airbags reduce injury in car crashes by extending the collision time, using impulse concepts.
A person jumps from a height and lands on a hard surface versus a soft mat. Compare the forces experienced using the impulse-momentum theorem.
A 70 kg stunt performer falls and experiences a momentum change of 420 kg·m/s. Compare the forces if the landing takes (a) 0.1 s or (b) 0.5 s.

sub_topics.name: Conservation of Momentum
sub_topics.short_description: Applying the law of conservation of momentum to isolated systems, understanding that total momentum before equals total momentum after interactions.

sub_topics.name: Isolated Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying isolated systems where no external forces act and momentum is conserved.
example_tasks: Explain why momentum is conserved for two colliding billiard balls but not for a ball falling under gravity.
Identify whether momentum is conserved in the following scenarios: (a) two ice skaters pushing off each other, (b) a car braking on a road, (c) astronauts in space pushing off each other.
A system consists of a person standing on a frictionless skateboard. If the person jumps off, explain why the skateboard moves backward using conservation of momentum.

sub_topics.name: One-Dimensional Momentum Conservation
sub_topics.short_description: Applying p_before = p_after to solve problems involving collisions or explosions along a single line.
example_tasks: A 5 kg cart moving at 4 m/s collides with a 3 kg cart at rest. After collision, they stick together. Find their common velocity.
Two ice skaters push off each other. Skater A (60 kg) moves at 2 m/s. If skater B (40 kg) was initially at rest, find their velocity after pushing off.
A 1200 kg car moving east at 15 m/s collides with a 1000 kg car moving west at 10 m/s. Find their combined velocity if they stick together.

sub_topics.name: Explosions and Recoil
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing situations where objects initially at rest separate, such as explosions or recoil, using momentum conservation.
example_tasks: A 4 kg firecracker at rest explodes into two pieces: a 1 kg piece and a 3 kg piece. If the 1 kg piece flies off at 12 m/s, find the velocity of the 3 kg piece.
A 50 kg astronaut floating at rest throws a 2 kg tool at 10 m/s. Calculate the astronaut's recoil velocity.
A cannon with mass 500 kg fires a 5 kg cannonball horizontally at 200 m/s. Find the recoil velocity of the cannon.

sub_topics.name: Two-Dimensional Momentum Conservation
sub_topics.short_description: Applying momentum conservation separately in x and y directions for two-dimensional collision problems.
example_tasks: Two pucks collide on a frictionless surface. Puck A (2 kg) moves east at 3 m/s, puck B (3 kg) moves north at 2 m/s. They stick together. Find the magnitude and direction of their combined velocity.
In a collision, momentum is conserved in both x and y directions. If initial momentum is (15 kg·m/s east, 20 kg·m/s north), find the final momentum vector.
A stationary nucleus decays into two fragments: one with momentum 40 kg·m/s at 30° and another with unknown momentum. Find the magnitude and direction of the second fragment's momentum.

sub_topics.name: Types of Collisions
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between elastic collisions (kinetic energy conserved) and inelastic collisions (kinetic energy not conserved), including perfectly inelastic collisions.

sub_topics.name: Elastic Collisions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding elastic collisions where both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved, typical of hard objects at low speeds.
example_tasks: Two identical 2 kg carts approach each other with speeds 3 m/s and 1 m/s. They collide elastically. Use conservation of momentum and energy to find their final velocities.
In an elastic collision, a 1 kg ball moving at 8 m/s hits a 3 kg ball at rest. Show that both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved if final velocities are 2 m/s and 2 m/s respectively.
Explain why billiard ball collisions are approximately elastic, while a car crash is highly inelastic.

sub_topics.name: Inelastic Collisions
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing inelastic collisions where momentum is conserved but kinetic energy is not, with energy converted to heat, sound, and deformation.
example_tasks: A 1500 kg car moving at 20 m/s collides with a 1000 kg car at rest. After an inelastic collision, they move together. Find their velocity and calculate the kinetic energy lost.
Two clay balls collide and stick together. Before collision: m₁ = 0.5 kg at 6 m/s, m₂ = 0.3 kg at -4 m/s. Find (a) final velocity and (b) percentage of kinetic energy lost.
Explain where the 'lost' kinetic energy goes in an inelastic collision, giving specific examples.

sub_topics.name: Perfectly Inelastic Collisions
sub_topics.short_description: Solving problems for perfectly inelastic collisions where objects stick together after collision, representing maximum kinetic energy loss.
example_tasks: A 60 kg person running at 5 m/s jumps onto a 20 kg stationary cart. Find their combined velocity after landing.
Two train cars couple together in a perfectly inelastic collision. Car A (10,000 kg at 8 m/s) couples with car B (5,000 kg at -2 m/s). Find their final velocity.
In a perfectly inelastic collision, a 3 kg object at 10 m/s hits a 7 kg object at rest. Calculate (a) final velocity and (b) fraction of kinetic energy lost.

sub_topics.name: Coefficient of Restitution
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the coefficient of restitution as a measure of elasticity in collisions, ranging from 0 (perfectly inelastic) to 1 (perfectly elastic).
example_tasks: A ball is dropped from height 2 m and bounces to height 1.5 m. Calculate the coefficient of restitution for the collision with the floor.
In a collision, e = 0.6. If the relative velocity of approach is 10 m/s, find the relative velocity of separation.
Explain what coefficient of restitution values of 0, 0.5, and 1.0 mean in terms of the collision type and energy conservation.

name: Rotational Motion and Gravitation
short_description: Introduction to rotational kinematics, torque, rotational dynamics, and Newton's law of universal gravitation. Students learn to describe and analyze rotating objects and gravitational interactions between masses.

sub_topics.name: Rotational Kinematics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding angular position, angular velocity, angular acceleration, and their relationships to linear quantities for rotating objects.

sub_topics.name: Angular Displacement and Velocity
sub_topics.short_description: Defining angular displacement in radians and angular velocity as rate of change of angle (ω = Δθ/Δt).
example_tasks: A wheel rotates through 5 complete revolutions. Convert this angular displacement to radians.
A disk rotates at 120 revolutions per minute (rpm). Convert this to angular velocity in rad/s.
A point on a rotating disk moves through an arc length of 10 m. If the radius is 2 m, calculate the angular displacement in radians.

sub_topics.name: Angular Acceleration
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding angular acceleration as rate of change of angular velocity (α = Δω/Δt) and solving rotational kinematics problems.
example_tasks: A flywheel accelerates from 10 rad/s to 30 rad/s in 5 seconds. Calculate the angular acceleration.
A wheel starts from rest and reaches 50 rad/s in 10 seconds with constant angular acceleration. Find α and the total angle rotated.
A spinning top slows from 40 rad/s to rest with angular acceleration -2 rad/s². How long does it take to stop and how many revolutions does it make?

sub_topics.name: Relating Linear and Angular Quantities
sub_topics.short_description: Converting between linear and angular quantities using s = rθ, v = rω, and a_tangential = rα.
example_tasks: A point on a wheel of radius 0.5 m has angular velocity 20 rad/s. Calculate its linear speed.
A car tire with radius 0.3 m rotates at 10 rev/s. Find (a) the angular velocity in rad/s and (b) the linear speed of a point on the tire's edge.
A merry-go-round with radius 4 m has angular acceleration 0.5 rad/s². Calculate the tangential acceleration of a child sitting at the edge.

sub_topics.name: Centripetal Acceleration in Rotation
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating centripetal acceleration for points on rotating objects using a_c = rω² or a_c = v²/r.
example_tasks: A point on a disk at radius 0.8 m rotates with angular velocity 15 rad/s. Calculate the centripetal acceleration.
Compare the centripetal accelerations of two points on a rotating platform: one at radius 1 m and another at radius 2 m, if ω = 5 rad/s.
Earth rotates once per day (T = 24 hours). Calculate the centripetal acceleration of a person standing at the equator (radius ≈ 6400 km).

sub_topics.name: Torque
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding torque as the rotational analog of force, calculating torque using τ = rF sin θ, and analyzing equilibrium conditions for rotating objects.

sub_topics.name: Definition of Torque
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding torque as the tendency of a force to cause rotation, calculated as τ = rF sin θ, measured in N·m.
example_tasks: A force of 20 N is applied perpendicular to a wrench 0.3 m from the bolt. Calculate the torque.
Explain why it's easier to open a door by pushing far from the hinges rather than close to them, using the concept of torque.
A force of 50 N is applied at an angle of 60° to a lever arm of length 0.4 m. Calculate the torque produced.

sub_topics.name: Clockwise and Counterclockwise Torque
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between torques that cause clockwise and counterclockwise rotation, using sign conventions.
example_tasks: Two forces act on a lever: 10 N downward at 0.5 m from the pivot and 15 N downward at 0.3 m on the opposite side. Calculate the net torque and direction of rotation.
Explain the sign convention for torque (positive for counterclockwise, negative for clockwise) and give an example.
A seesaw has children sitting on both sides. If the torques are equal in magnitude but opposite in direction, what happens to the seesaw?

sub_topics.name: Lever Arm and Torque
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the lever arm (perpendicular distance from pivot to line of force) and its role in torque calculation.
example_tasks: A force of 30 N is applied horizontally to a door 0.8 m from the hinges. The door handle is positioned at 90° to the door surface. Calculate the torque.
Identify the lever arm for a force applied at an angle to a wrench, and explain why the perpendicular component matters.
A force is applied directly toward the pivot point. Explain why this produces zero torque regardless of the force magnitude.

sub_topics.name: Rotational Equilibrium
sub_topics.short_description: Applying the condition for rotational equilibrium: sum of clockwise torques equals sum of counterclockwise torques (Στ = 0).
example_tasks: A 5 m uniform beam is supported at its center. A 20 N weight hangs 1 m from the left end. Where should a 30 N weight be placed to balance the beam?
A seesaw has a pivot at its center. A 40 kg child sits 2 m from the pivot. How far from the pivot should a 30 kg child sit to balance?
A uniform 10 kg plank 4 m long rests on two supports, one at each end. A 30 kg person stands 1 m from the left end. Calculate the forces exerted by each support.

sub_topics.name: Moment of Inertia Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Introduction to moment of inertia as rotational analog of mass, understanding how mass distribution affects rotational motion.

sub_topics.name: Concept of Moment of Inertia
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding moment of inertia (I) as resistance to rotational acceleration, depending on mass and its distribution from the axis.
example_tasks: Explain why it's harder to spin a bat when holding it at the narrow end compared to holding it at the thick end.
Compare the moments of inertia of two identical masses: one concentrated at the axis of rotation and one far from the axis.
Describe how a figure skater reduces their moment of inertia by pulling their arms in during a spin.

sub_topics.name: Calculating Simple Moments of Inertia
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating moment of inertia for point masses using I = mr² and for systems of point masses using I = Σmr².
example_tasks: Calculate the moment of inertia of a 2 kg point mass located 0.5 m from the axis of rotation.
Two 3 kg masses are attached to opposite ends of a massless rod 2 m long. Calculate the moment of inertia when rotated about the center.
Four equal masses (m = 1 kg each) are arranged at the corners of a square with side 0.4 m. Calculate the moment of inertia about an axis through the center perpendicular to the square.

sub_topics.name: Rotational Newton's Second Law
sub_topics.short_description: Applying the rotational form of Newton's second law: τ = Iα, relating torque to angular acceleration.
example_tasks: A torque of 10 N·m is applied to a wheel with moment of inertia 5 kg·m². Calculate the angular acceleration.
A disk with I = 0.8 kg·m² experiences angular acceleration of 4 rad/s². Calculate the net torque acting on it.
Compare the angular accelerations of two wheels with the same applied torque but different moments of inertia: I₁ = 2 kg·m² and I₂ = 4 kg·m².

sub_topics.name: Universal Gravitation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Newton's law of universal gravitation, calculating gravitational forces between masses, and applying concepts to orbital motion.

sub_topics.name: Newton's Law of Gravitation
sub_topics.short_description: Applying F = Gm₁m₂/r² to calculate gravitational force between two masses, understanding the universal gravitational constant G.
example_tasks: Calculate the gravitational force between two 100 kg masses separated by 2 m (G = 6.67 × 10⁻¹¹ N·m²/kg²).
The gravitational force between Earth (6 × 10²⁴ kg) and a 70 kg person is 686 N at Earth's surface. Estimate Earth's radius using Newton's law of gravitation.
Explain why gravitational force between everyday objects is negligible but significant between astronomical objects.

sub_topics.name: Gravitational Field Strength
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding gravitational field strength (g = GM/r²) and how it varies with distance from a massive object.
example_tasks: Calculate the gravitational field strength at Earth's surface given M_Earth = 6 × 10²⁴ kg and R_Earth = 6.4 × 10⁶ m.
At what altitude above Earth's surface is the gravitational field strength half its surface value?
Compare the gravitational field strength at the surface of Mars (M = 6.4 × 10²³ kg, R = 3.4 × 10⁶ m) to that at Earth's surface.

sub_topics.name: Orbital Motion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding circular orbital motion where gravitational force provides centripetal force, relating orbital speed to radius.
example_tasks: A satellite orbits Earth at radius 7 × 10⁶ m. Use the fact that gravitational force provides centripetal force to calculate the orbital speed.
Explain why astronauts in orbit experience 'weightlessness' even though gravitational force acts on them.
Derive the relationship between orbital period and orbital radius for a satellite, showing that T² ∝ r³ (Kepler's third law).

sub_topics.name: Gravitational Potential Energy (Advanced)
sub_topics.short_description: Introduction to gravitational potential energy for large distances: PE = -GMm/r, understanding negative energy convention.
example_tasks: Calculate the gravitational potential energy of a 1000 kg satellite at Earth's surface using PE = -GMm/r.
Explain why gravitational potential energy is negative and what PE = 0 represents (object at infinite distance).
How much energy is required to move a 500 kg satellite from Earth's surface (r = 6.4 × 10⁶ m) to an orbital altitude where r = 7.0 × 10⁶ m?

name: Thermal Physics and Heat Transfer
short_description: Understanding temperature, heat, thermal properties of matter, and mechanisms of heat transfer. Students learn to distinguish between heat and temperature, apply calorimetry principles, and analyze thermal expansion and phase changes.

sub_topics.name: Temperature and Heat
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between temperature as average kinetic energy of particles and heat as energy transfer due to temperature difference.

sub_topics.name: Temperature Scales
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Celsius, Fahrenheit, and Kelvin temperature scales and converting between them.
example_tasks: Convert 25°C to Kelvin and to Fahrenheit using the appropriate conversion formulas.
Explain why the Kelvin scale is called an absolute temperature scale and what 0 K represents.
Water freezes at 0°C and boils at 100°C at standard pressure. Express these temperatures in Kelvin and Fahrenheit.

sub_topics.name: Kinetic Theory and Temperature
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding temperature as a measure of average kinetic energy of particles in a substance.
example_tasks: Explain why increasing the temperature of a gas increases the average speed of its molecules.
Two containers hold the same gas at different temperatures. Compare the average kinetic energies of molecules in each container.
Describe what happens to particle motion as temperature approaches absolute zero.

sub_topics.name: Heat vs. Temperature
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between heat (energy in transit) and temperature (measure of thermal energy), understanding that heat flows from hot to cold.
example_tasks: Explain why a large lake at 20°C contains more thermal energy than a cup of boiling water at 100°C.
A metal spoon is placed in hot soup. Describe the heat transfer process and explain why the handle becomes warm.
Two objects at different temperatures are placed in contact. Use the concept of heat flow to predict what happens to their temperatures over time.

sub_topics.name: Thermal Equilibrium
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding thermal equilibrium as the state where two objects in contact reach the same temperature and heat flow stops.
example_tasks: A hot metal block is placed in cool water. Describe the heat transfer until thermal equilibrium is reached.
Explain the zeroth law of thermodynamics: if object A is in thermal equilibrium with object C, and object B is in thermal equilibrium with object C, then A and B are in thermal equilibrium.
A thermometer measures temperature by coming into thermal equilibrium with the object being measured. Explain how this works.

sub_topics.name: Specific Heat Capacity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding specific heat capacity as the amount of heat needed to change the temperature of a substance, and using Q = mcΔT in calculations.

sub_topics.name: Defining Specific Heat Capacity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding specific heat capacity (c) as heat required per unit mass per degree temperature change, measured in J/(kg·°C).
example_tasks: Water has a specific heat capacity of 4186 J/(kg·°C). Explain what this value means in practical terms.
Compare substances with high specific heat (like water) and low specific heat (like metals). Which heats up faster with the same energy input?
Explain why coastal areas have more moderate temperatures than inland areas, using the concept of water's high specific heat capacity.

sub_topics.name: Heat Transfer Calculations
sub_topics.short_description: Using Q = mcΔT to calculate heat transferred, mass, specific heat, or temperature change in thermal processes.
example_tasks: Calculate the heat required to raise the temperature of 2 kg of water from 20°C to 80°C (c_water = 4186 J/(kg·°C)).
A 500 g aluminum block (c = 900 J/(kg·°C)) absorbs 18,000 J of heat. Calculate the temperature change.
An unknown metal sample with mass 300 g absorbs 4500 J of heat and its temperature increases by 25°C. Calculate its specific heat capacity and identify the possible metal.

sub_topics.name: Calorimetry Problems
sub_topics.short_description: Solving calorimetry problems where heat lost by hot objects equals heat gained by cold objects in an isolated system.
example_tasks: A 200 g piece of hot metal at 150°C is placed in 500 g of water at 20°C. The final temperature is 30°C. Calculate the specific heat of the metal.
In a calorimeter, 100 g of water at 80°C is mixed with 200 g of water at 20°C. Calculate the final equilibrium temperature (ignore heat absorbed by the calorimeter).
A 50 g ice cube at 0°C is added to 200 g of water at 50°C. If the final temperature is 25°C, calculate the heat of fusion of ice (c_water = 4186 J/(kg·°C)).

sub_topics.name: Thermal Expansion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that most materials expand when heated and contract when cooled, and calculating linear and volume expansion.

sub_topics.name: Linear Expansion
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating change in length of materials due to temperature change using ΔL = αL₀ΔT, where α is the coefficient of linear expansion.
example_tasks: A 10 m steel beam has a coefficient of linear expansion α = 12 × 10⁻⁶ /°C. Calculate its length change when temperature increases from 20°C to 60°C.
Explain why bridges have expansion joints and what would happen without them during temperature changes.
