A concrete sidewalk 50 m long expands by 3 cm when the temperature rises 40°C. Calculate the coefficient of linear expansion for concrete.

sub_topics.name: Volume Expansion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding volume expansion of liquids and gases using ΔV = βV₀ΔT, where β is the coefficient of volume expansion.
example_tasks: A gasoline tank holds 50 L at 15°C. If the temperature rises to 35°C and β_gasoline = 950 × 10⁻⁶ /°C, calculate the volume change.
Explain why thermometers use mercury or alcohol: relate to volume expansion with temperature.
A glass container is filled to the brim with 1 L of water at 20°C. Both glass and water expand when heated. If heated to 80°C, will water overflow? (β_water = 210 × 10⁻⁶ /°C, β_glass = 27 × 10⁻⁶ /°C)

sub_topics.name: Applications of Thermal Expansion
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing real-world applications and problems related to thermal expansion in engineering and everyday life.
example_tasks: Explain how a bimetallic strip thermostat works, using the concept of different expansion rates for different metals.
Power lines are installed with some slack in summer. Explain why this is necessary using thermal expansion concepts.
A glass bottle with a tight metal lid is difficult to open. Explain why running hot water over the lid helps, using thermal expansion.

sub_topics.name: Phase Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding phase transitions between solid, liquid, and gas, including latent heat of fusion and vaporization, and energy considerations during phase changes.

sub_topics.name: States of Matter
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the three common states of matter and the molecular differences between solid, liquid, and gas phases.
example_tasks: Describe the arrangement and motion of particles in solid, liquid, and gas phases.
Explain why solids have definite shape and volume, liquids have definite volume but not shape, and gases have neither.
Compare the intermolecular forces in ice, liquid water, and water vapor.

sub_topics.name: Phase Change Processes
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying phase transitions: melting, freezing, vaporization, condensation, sublimation, and deposition.
example_tasks: Identify the phase change occurring in each scenario: (a) ice forming on a windshield, (b) water boiling in a pot, (c) dew forming on grass, (d) dry ice disappearing.
Draw a diagram showing all six phase transitions between solid, liquid, and gas states. Label each transition.
Explain why evaporation is a cooling process, using molecular kinetic energy concepts.

sub_topics.name: Latent Heat
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding latent heat as energy required for phase change without temperature change, using Q = mL for fusion and vaporization.
example_tasks: Calculate the energy required to melt 2 kg of ice at 0°C to water at 0°C (L_fusion = 3.34 × 10⁵ J/kg).
Why does water at 100°C cause more severe burns than steam at 100°C? Explain using latent heat of vaporization (L_vap = 2.26 × 10⁶ J/kg).
How much energy is released when 500 g of water vapor at 100°C condenses to liquid water at 100°C?

sub_topics.name: Heating and Cooling Curves
sub_topics.short_description: Interpreting temperature vs. time graphs showing heating of substances through phase changes, identifying plateau regions.
example_tasks: Sketch a heating curve for ice starting at -20°C and ending as steam at 120°C. Label all phase changes and indicate where temperature remains constant.

Calculate the total energy needed to convert 100 g of ice at -10°C to steam at 110°C (use c_ice = 2100 J/(kg·°C), c_water = 4186 J/(kg·°C), c_steam = 2000 J/(kg·°C), L_f = 3.34 × 10⁵ J/kg, L_v = 2.26 × 10⁶ J/kg).
Explain why the temperature remains constant during melting and boiling, even though heat is being added continuously.

sub_topics.name: Heat Transfer Mechanisms
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the three methods of heat transfer: conduction, convection, and radiation, and analyzing heat transfer in various situations.

sub_topics.name: Conduction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding heat transfer through direct contact in solids, role of thermal conductivity, and factors affecting conduction rate.
example_tasks: Explain why a metal spoon feels colder than a wooden spoon at room temperature, using the concept of thermal conductivity.
List three good thermal conductors and three good thermal insulators. Explain applications of each.
Describe how heat transfers from a hot stove burner through a metal pot to water inside, identifying the conduction process.

sub_topics.name: Convection
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding heat transfer through fluid motion (liquids and gases), distinguishing between natural and forced convection.
example_tasks: Explain why hot air rises and cold air sinks, using the concepts of density and convection currents.
Describe the convection currents that form when heating water in a pot on a stove. Draw a diagram showing the circulation pattern.
Give three examples of convection in everyday life (e.g., heating systems, weather patterns, ocean currents) and explain each.

sub_topics.name: Radiation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding heat transfer through electromagnetic waves without requiring a medium, and factors affecting radiation rate.
example_tasks: Explain how the Sun's energy reaches Earth through the vacuum of space, using the concept of thermal radiation.
Why do people wear light-colored clothing in summer and dark-colored clothing in winter? Relate to absorption and emission of thermal radiation.
Compare the rates of heat loss by radiation for a shiny aluminum surface versus a black painted surface at the same temperature.

sub_topics.name: Comparing Heat Transfer Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing situations involving multiple heat transfer mechanisms and determining the dominant method.
example_tasks: For a cup of hot coffee cooling in a room, identify all three heat transfer methods involved and explain each.
Explain how a thermos bottle (vacuum flask) minimizes heat transfer by reducing conduction, convection, and radiation.
A house loses heat in winter through walls (conduction), air leaks (convection), and windows (radiation). Suggest improvements to reduce each type of heat loss.

sub_topics.name: Thermal Energy and Internal Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding internal energy as the total energy of particles in a substance, and the relationship between heat, work, and internal energy.

sub_topics.name: Internal Energy Concept
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding internal energy as the sum of kinetic and potential energies of all particles in a substance.
example_tasks: Explain how the internal energy of a gas changes when its temperature increases.
Compare the internal energy of 1 kg of water at 20°C to 1 kg of water at 80°C.
Describe what happens to internal energy during a phase change from ice to water at 0°C.

sub_topics.name: First Law of Thermodynamics (Introduction)
sub_topics.short_description: Introduction to the first law: change in internal energy equals heat added minus work done by the system (ΔU = Q - W).
example_tasks: A gas absorbs 500 J of heat and does 200 J of work expanding. Calculate the change in internal energy.
Explain why compressing a gas (doing work on it) increases its temperature, using the first law of thermodynamics.
A system's internal energy increases by 300 J while 400 J of heat is added. Determine whether the system did work or had work done on it, and how much.

sub_topics.name: Heat Engines (Introduction)
sub_topics.short_description: Basic introduction to heat engines as devices that convert thermal energy to mechanical work, understanding efficiency concepts.
example_tasks: A heat engine absorbs 1000 J from a hot reservoir and exhausts 600 J to a cold reservoir. Calculate the work output and efficiency.
Explain why no heat engine can be 100% efficient at converting heat to work.
List three examples of heat engines (e.g., car engine, power plant, refrigerator) and briefly describe how each operates.

name: Wave Properties and Behavior
short_description: Understanding mechanical waves, wave characteristics, wave phenomena including reflection, refraction, diffraction, and interference. Students learn to describe waves mathematically and analyze wave behavior in various media.

sub_topics.name: Wave Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between mechanical and electromagnetic waves, transverse and longitudinal waves, and understanding wave motion versus particle motion.

sub_topics.name: Types of Waves
sub_topics.short_description: Classifying waves as mechanical (requiring medium) or electromagnetic (no medium needed), and as transverse or longitudinal based on particle motion.
example_tasks: Categorize the following as mechanical or electromagnetic waves: sound, light, water waves, radio waves, seismic waves.
Draw diagrams comparing transverse and longitudinal waves, showing particle displacement relative to wave direction.
Explain why sound cannot travel through a vacuum but light can, using the concepts of mechanical and electromagnetic waves.

sub_topics.name: Transverse and Longitudinal Waves
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding particle motion in transverse waves (perpendicular to wave direction) versus longitudinal waves (parallel to wave direction).
example_tasks: Describe the motion of water molecules as a water wave passes. Is this transverse, longitudinal, or a combination?
Use a slinky to model transverse and longitudinal waves. Describe the particle motion in each case.
Sound waves are longitudinal. Explain what this means in terms of air molecule motion as sound travels through air.

sub_topics.name: Wave Pulse vs. Periodic Wave
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between a single wave pulse and a continuous periodic wave train.
example_tasks: Give examples of wave pulses (e.g., single snap of a rope) and periodic waves (e.g., continuous shaking of a rope).
Sketch a wave pulse traveling along a rope and describe what happens to the rope as the pulse passes.
Explain how a periodic wave differs from a single pulse in terms of energy transfer and pattern.

sub_topics.name: Wave Characteristics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding and measuring wave properties including wavelength, frequency, period, amplitude, and wave speed, and their relationships.

sub_topics.name: Wavelength and Amplitude
sub_topics.short_description: Defining wavelength (λ) as distance between successive crests and amplitude (A) as maximum displacement from equilibrium.
example_tasks: Identify and measure the wavelength and amplitude on a given wave diagram.
A wave has wavelength 2 m and amplitude 0.5 m. Sketch this wave showing at least two complete cycles.
Explain the difference between wavelength and amplitude, and describe how changing each affects the wave.

sub_topics.name: Frequency and Period
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding frequency (f) as cycles per second and period (T) as time for one cycle, with the relationship f = 1/T.
example_tasks: A wave has a period of 0.2 seconds. Calculate its frequency.
A wave source vibrates at 50 Hz. Calculate the period of the wave.
Explain the relationship between frequency and period. If frequency doubles, what happens to period?

sub_topics.name: Wave Speed
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating wave speed using v = fλ and understanding that wave speed depends on the medium, not the source.
example_tasks: A wave has frequency 10 Hz and wavelength 3 m. Calculate the wave speed.
Sound waves travel at 340 m/s in air. If a sound has frequency 440 Hz, calculate its wavelength.
A water wave has wavelength 5 m and travels at 15 m/s. Calculate (a) the frequency and (b) the period.

sub_topics.name: Energy in Waves
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that waves transport energy without transporting matter, and that energy is proportional to amplitude squared.
example_tasks: Explain how ocean waves can transport energy across vast distances without moving water across those distances.
If the amplitude of a wave is doubled, by what factor does the energy transported increase?
Describe how energy is carried by a sound wave through air, noting that air molecules don't travel from source to listener.

sub_topics.name: Wave Behavior at Boundaries
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding reflection, transmission, and impedance matching when waves encounter boundaries between different media.

sub_topics.name: Reflection at Fixed and Free Ends
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that waves reflect inverted at fixed boundaries and upright at free boundaries.
example_tasks: A wave pulse travels along a rope toward a fixed end (tied to a wall). Describe and sketch the reflected pulse.
A wave pulse travels along a rope toward a free end (loose ring on a pole). Describe and sketch the reflected pulse.
Explain why a wave reflects inverted from a fixed end but upright from a free end, using the concepts of forces and displacements.

sub_topics.name: Transmission and Refraction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how waves partially transmit and reflect at boundaries, and how wave speed changes affect direction (refraction).
example_tasks: A wave travels from a thick rope to a thin rope. Describe what happens in terms of reflection and transmission.
Explain why waves slow down when entering a denser medium and speed up when entering a less dense medium.
Water waves approaching a beach at an angle slow down as they enter shallow water. Describe how the wave direction changes (refraction).

sub_topics.name: Impedance Matching
sub_topics.short_description: Introduction to impedance and understanding that impedance mismatch causes reflection while matching allows full transmission.
example_tasks: Explain why ultrasound technicians use gel on skin during examinations, relating to impedance matching.
Describe what happens when a sound wave traveling through air encounters a water surface in terms of reflection and transmission.
Compare the reflection of waves at boundaries with large impedance differences versus small impedance differences.

sub_topics.name: Superposition and Interference
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the principle of superposition and analyzing constructive and destructive interference patterns when waves overlap.

sub_topics.name: Principle of Superposition
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that when waves overlap, the resultant displacement is the sum of individual displacements.
example_tasks: Two wave pulses with amplitudes +3 cm and +2 cm overlap at the same point. What is the resultant amplitude at that instant?
Sketch the resultant wave when two identical waves traveling in opposite directions overlap completely.
Explain the principle of superposition using the example of two people shaking opposite ends of a rope simultaneously.

sub_topics.name: Constructive Interference
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding constructive interference occurs when waves combine in phase, resulting in increased amplitude.
example_tasks: Two identical waves with amplitude 5 cm meet in phase. What is the amplitude of the resultant wave?
Describe the conditions necessary for maximum constructive interference between two waves.
Sketch two waves and their superposition when they interfere constructively at a particular location.

sub_topics.name: Destructive Interference
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding destructive interference occurs when waves combine out of phase, resulting in reduced or zero amplitude.
example_tasks: Two identical waves with amplitude 4 cm meet exactly out of phase (180° phase difference). What is the resultant amplitude?
Explain how noise-canceling headphones use destructive interference to reduce unwanted sound.
Sketch two waves and their superposition when they interfere destructively, showing complete cancellation.

sub_topics.name: Standing Waves
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding standing waves as interference patterns of waves traveling in opposite directions, identifying nodes and antinodes.
example_tasks: Describe how a standing wave forms on a string fixed at both ends when waves reflect back and forth.
Identify the locations of nodes (points of zero displacement) and antinodes (points of maximum displacement) on a standing wave diagram.
A string 2 m long fixed at both ends vibrates in its fundamental mode. What is the wavelength of the standing wave?

sub_topics.name: Diffraction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding diffraction as the bending of waves around obstacles or through openings, and factors affecting diffraction amount.

sub_topics.name: Diffraction Concept
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that waves bend around obstacles and spread out after passing through openings.
example_tasks: Explain why you can hear someone talking around a corner even though you can't see them, using the concept of diffraction.
Describe what happens to water waves when they pass through a narrow opening in a barrier.
Compare the diffraction of light and sound waves, explaining why sound diffracts more noticeably around everyday obstacles.

sub_topics.name: Factors Affecting Diffraction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that diffraction is most pronounced when the wavelength is comparable to the size of the obstacle or opening.
example_tasks: Explain why AM radio waves (long wavelength) diffract around hills better than FM radio waves (shorter wavelength).
Compare the diffraction of waves passing through a wide opening versus a narrow opening of similar wavelength.
A wave with wavelength 2 cm approaches an opening of width 2 cm. Predict whether significant diffraction will occur and explain.

sub_topics.name: Applications of Diffraction
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing practical examples and applications of wave diffraction in everyday phenomena and technology.
example_tasks: Explain why ship foghorns use low-frequency sound to maximize diffraction around obstacles.
Describe how diffraction affects the reception of TV and radio signals in mountainous terrain.
Ocean waves approaching a harbor entrance diffract and spread into the harbor. Draw a diagram showing the wave pattern before and after the entrance.

sub_topics.name: Doppler Effect (Introduction)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that wave frequency appears to change when the source or observer is moving, introducing the basic concept without complex calculations.

sub_topics.name: Doppler Effect Concept
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that approaching sources have increased observed frequency while receding sources have decreased observed frequency.
example_tasks: Explain why a siren sounds higher-pitched as an ambulance approaches and lower-pitched as it moves away.
Describe what happens to the wavelength and frequency of waves in front of and behind a moving source.
A car honks while driving past you. Sketch a diagram showing the compressed wavelengths ahead and stretched wavelengths behind.

sub_topics.name: Doppler Effect Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying real-world applications of the Doppler effect in everyday life and technology.
example_tasks: Explain how police radar guns use the Doppler effect to measure vehicle speed.
Describe how astronomers use the Doppler effect to determine whether stars are moving toward or away from Earth (redshift and blueshift).
Medical ultrasound uses the Doppler effect to measure blood flow. Explain the basic principle of how this works.

name: Sound Waves and Acoustics
short_description: Understanding sound as longitudinal mechanical waves, properties of sound including pitch, loudness, and timbre, sound wave behavior, and applications in acoustics. Students learn to analyze sound mathematically and understand resonance phenomena.

sub_topics.name: Nature of Sound
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding sound as longitudinal pressure waves in a medium, speed of sound in different materials, and requirement for a medium.

sub_topics.name: Sound as Pressure Waves
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding sound waves as traveling compressions and rarefactions (pressure variations) in a medium.
example_tasks: Describe the motion of air molecules as a sound wave passes through air, identifying compressions and rarefactions.
Explain why sound is classified as a longitudinal wave using the motion of particles in the medium.
Draw a diagram showing regions of compression (high pressure) and rarefaction (low pressure) in a sound wave.

sub_topics.name: Speed of Sound
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that sound speed depends on the medium's properties, comparing speeds in solids, liquids, and gases.
example_tasks: The speed of sound in air at 20°C is approximately 343 m/s. Calculate the time for sound to travel 1 km.
Compare the speed of sound in air (343 m/s), water (1480 m/s), and steel (5960 m/s). Explain why sound travels fastest in solids.
A lightning flash is seen, and thunder is heard 3 seconds later. Calculate the distance to the lightning strike.

sub_topics.name: Sound Requires a Medium
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that sound cannot travel through a vacuum because it requires particles to transmit compressions.
example_tasks: Explain why astronauts in space cannot hear each other without radio communication, even if very close.
Describe the classic bell-in-vacuum experiment that demonstrates sound requires a medium.
Compare how sound and light travel through space, explaining why we can see but not hear distant explosions in space movies.

sub_topics.name: Properties of Sound
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding pitch (frequency), loudness (amplitude and intensity), and timbre (quality), and their physical bases.

sub_topics.name: Pitch and Frequency
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding pitch as the perceived frequency of sound, with higher frequency corresponding to higher pitch.
example_tasks: Explain the relationship between the frequency of a sound wave and the pitch we perceive.
The human hearing range is approximately 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz. Identify sounds below (infrasound) and above (ultrasound) this range.
A guitar string vibrates at 440 Hz (concert A). If the string is tightened to vibrate at 880 Hz, describe how the pitch changes.

sub_topics.name: Loudness, Amplitude, and Intensity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding loudness as related to wave amplitude and intensity (power per unit area), measured in decibels.
example_tasks: Explain how the amplitude of a sound wave relates to the loudness we perceive.
Describe the decibel scale and explain why it is logarithmic. Give examples of sound levels in dB (whisper ~30 dB, conversation ~60 dB, rock concert ~110 dB).
If sound intensity is increased by a factor of 10, by how many decibels does the sound level increase?

sub_topics.name: Timbre and Quality
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding timbre as the quality of sound that distinguishes different sources at the same pitch and loudness, due to harmonic content.
example_tasks: Explain why a piano and a violin sound different even when playing the same note at the same loudness.
Describe how overtones and harmonics contribute to the timbre of musical instruments.
Compare the waveforms of a pure tone (single frequency) and a complex tone (multiple frequencies) and relate to timbre.

sub_topics.name: Sound Wave Behaviors
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing reflection (echoes), refraction, diffraction, and interference of sound waves in various environments.

sub_topics.name: Reflection and Echoes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding sound reflection from surfaces, echo formation, and applications in sonar and echolocation.
example_tasks: A person shouts toward a cliff 340 m away. How long after shouting will the echo be heard? (v_sound = 340 m/s)
Explain how bats use echolocation to navigate and hunt, using the principles of sound reflection.
Describe how sonar systems on ships use reflected sound waves to map the ocean floor and detect objects.

sub_topics.name: Refraction of Sound
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that sound waves refract when speed changes due to temperature or density variations in the medium.
example_tasks: Explain why sound travels farther at night over a lake due to temperature gradients causing refraction.
Describe how sound waves bend when traveling from warm air into cool air, using the concept of refraction.
Sound speed increases with temperature. Explain how this causes sound waves to curve back toward the ground on a hot day.

sub_topics.name: Diffraction of Sound
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why sound diffracts significantly around everyday obstacles due to its relatively long wavelength.
example_tasks: Explain why you can hear a conversation around a corner even though you cannot see the speakers.
Compare the diffraction of high-frequency sounds (short wavelength) and low-frequency sounds (long wavelength) around obstacles.
Describe how the design of concert halls takes advantage of sound diffraction to distribute sound evenly to the audience.

sub_topics.name: Interference of Sound
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding constructive and destructive interference of sound waves creating regions of loud and soft sound.
example_tasks: Two speakers emit identical sound waves in phase. Explain where a listener would hear loud sound (constructive interference) and soft sound (destructive interference).
Describe the phenomenon of beats: when two sound waves of slightly different frequencies interfere, producing a periodic variation in loudness.
Calculate the beat frequency when two tuning forks with frequencies 256 Hz and 260 Hz are struck simultaneously.

sub_topics.name: Resonance in Sound
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding resonance as vibration at natural frequencies, analyzing standing waves in strings and air columns, and harmonics.

sub_topics.name: Natural Frequency and Resonance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that objects have natural frequencies at which they vibrate most easily, and resonance occurs when driven at these frequencies.
example_tasks: Explain why a tuning fork will cause another identical tuning fork nearby to vibrate (sympathetic resonance).
Describe what happens when a singer matches the natural frequency of a wine glass with their voice (glass shatters at resonance).
Give three examples of resonance in everyday life and explain the potential benefits or dangers of each.

sub_topics.name: Standing Waves in Strings
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing harmonics and standing wave patterns in vibrating strings, calculating wavelengths and frequencies.
example_tasks: A guitar string 0.6 m long is fixed at both ends. Calculate the wavelength of the fundamental frequency (first harmonic).
Describe the first three harmonics (modes of vibration) of a vibrating string, sketching the standing wave patterns and identifying nodes and antinodes.
A string has fundamental frequency 200 Hz. Calculate the frequencies of the second and third harmonics.

sub_topics.name: Standing Waves in Air Columns
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding standing waves in open and closed pipes, determining resonant frequencies and harmonics in wind instruments.
example_tasks: An open pipe (open at both ends) has length 0.5 m. Calculate the fundamental frequency if the speed of sound is 340 m/s.
Compare the harmonics present in an open pipe versus a closed pipe (closed at one end). Explain why closed pipes only produce odd harmonics.
A closed organ pipe has fundamental frequency 100 Hz. Calculate the frequencies of the next two harmonics (3rd and 5th).

sub_topics.name: Musical Instruments and Acoustics
sub_topics.short_description: Applying resonance concepts to understand how different musical instruments produce and control sound.
example_tasks: Explain how a guitarist changes the pitch of a note by pressing the string at different frets, using the concept of standing waves.
Describe how a flute player changes pitch by opening and closing holes along the instrument's length.
Compare how string instruments (guitar, violin) and wind instruments (flute, trumpet) produce different pitches using resonance principles.

sub_topics.name: Doppler Effect for Sound
sub_topics.short_description: Applying the Doppler effect to sound waves, calculating observed frequency changes for moving sources and observers.

sub_topics.name: Moving Source
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding and calculating observed frequency when the sound source moves toward or away from a stationary observer.
example_tasks: A car horn has frequency 500 Hz. Qualitatively describe the frequency heard by a stationary observer as the car approaches and then recedes.
Explain using wave diagrams why wavelength is compressed in front of a moving source and stretched behind it.
A train whistle has frequency 600 Hz. If the train approaches at 30 m/s, will the observed frequency be higher or lower? Explain qualitatively.

sub_topics.name: Moving Observer
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding observed frequency changes when the observer moves toward or away from a stationary sound source.
example_tasks: Explain what happens to the observed frequency when you run toward a stationary sound source versus running away from it.
Describe the difference between a moving source and a moving observer in terms of their effects on observed frequency.
A person drives toward a stationary siren. Compare this situation to the siren moving toward a stationary person in terms of perceived frequency.

sub_topics.name: Applications of Doppler Effect in Sound
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing practical applications of the Doppler effect including radar guns, medical imaging, and weather monitoring.
example_tasks: Explain how a police radar gun uses the Doppler effect of radio waves to measure vehicle speed.
Describe how Doppler ultrasound is used in medicine to measure blood flow velocity and detect heart problems.
Meteorologists use Doppler radar to detect rotation in thunderstorms. Explain the basic principle of how this works.

name: Introduction to Electricity
short_description: Understanding electric charge, electric force, electric fields, and electric potential. Students learn fundamental concepts of electrostatics and the behavior of charged objects.

sub_topics.name: Electric Charge
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding electric charge as a fundamental property, types of charge (positive and negative), conservation of charge, and charging methods.

sub_topics.name: Properties of Electric Charge
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that charge comes in two types (positive and negative), like charges repel, opposite charges attract, and charge is quantized.
example_tasks: Explain why a rubbed balloon sticks to a wall using the concepts of electric charge and attraction.
Describe what happens when two positively charged objects are brought near each other, and when a positive and negative object are brought near each other.
The elementary charge is e = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C. Explain what this means and why all charges are integer multiples of this value.

sub_topics.name: Conservation of Charge
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that the total electric charge in an isolated system remains constant; charge cannot be created or destroyed.
example_tasks: A neutral object is rubbed with a cloth. The object becomes positively charged. What happened to the electrons, and what is the charge on the cloth?
Initially, two metal spheres are neutral and touching. They are separated after being charged. If one has +3 μC, what charge does the other have?
Explain how conservation of charge applies during the process of charging by friction (e.g., rubbing a glass rod with silk).

sub_topics.name: Methods of Charging
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding three methods of charging objects: friction, conduction, and induction.
example_tasks: Describe how rubbing a balloon on hair charges the balloon by friction. Where do the electrons go?
Explain charging by conduction: a charged rod touches a neutral metal sphere. What happens to the charge?
Describe charging by induction: how a neutral metal sphere can be given a charge opposite to a nearby charged rod without touching.

sub_topics.name: Conductors vs. Insulators
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between conductors (allow charge flow) and insulators (resist charge flow), and understanding charge distribution.
example_tasks: Categorize the following as conductors or insulators: copper wire, glass, salt water, plastic, aluminum foil, wood.
Explain why electric wires are made of copper (conductor) but covered with rubber (insulator).
Describe what happens to excess charge placed on a conductor versus an insulator in terms of charge distribution.

sub_topics.name: Coulomb's Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding and applying Coulomb's law to calculate electric forces between charged objects.

sub_topics.name: Coulomb's Law Formula
sub_topics.short_description: Applying F = k|q₁q₂|/r² to calculate the magnitude of electric force, understanding the role of the constant k = 9 × 10⁹ N·m²/C².
example_tasks: Calculate the electric force between two point charges: q₁ = +2 μC and q₂ = -3 μC separated by 0.5 m. (Use k = 9 × 10⁹ N·m²/C²)
Two identical charges separated by 0.2 m exert a force of 0.9 N on each other. Calculate the magnitude of each charge.
How does the electric force change if the distance between two charges is tripled? Explain using Coulomb's law.

sub_topics.name: Comparing Electric and Gravitational Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing the forms and strengths of Coulomb's law and Newton's law of gravitation.
example_tasks: Compare the mathematical forms of Coulomb's law (F = kq₁q₂/r²) and Newton's law of gravitation (F = Gm₁m₂/r²). What are the similarities and differences?
Calculate both the electric force and gravitational force between an electron and proton in a hydrogen atom (separated by ~5 × 10⁻¹¹ m). Which is stronger?
Explain why gravitational force is always attractive while electric force can be attractive or repulsive.

sub_topics.name: Net Electric Force
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating the net electric force on a charge due to multiple other charges using vector addition.
example_tasks: Three charges are arranged in a line: q₁ = +2 μC at x = 0, q₂ = -4 μC at x = 0.3 m, and q₃ = +3 μC at x = 0.6 m. Calculate the net force on q₂.
A charge +Q is placed at the origin. Identical charges +q are placed at (1 m, 0) and (0, 1 m). Find the direction of the net force on one of the +q charges.
Four identical positive charges are placed at the corners of a square. Describe the net electric force on one of the charges using symmetry arguments.

sub_topics.name: Electric Fields
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding electric fields as regions where electric forces act, calculating field strength, and visualizing fields with field lines.

sub_topics.name: Electric Field Concept
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding electric field as force per unit charge (E = F/q), existing around any charged object.
example_tasks: Define electric field and explain why it's useful to think of a field rather than just forces between charges.
A test charge of +2 × 10⁻⁶ C experiences a force of 0.4 N in an electric field. Calculate the electric field strength.
Explain the direction convention: electric field points in the direction a positive test charge would be pushed.

sub_topics.name: Calculating Electric Fields
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating electric field magnitude using E = kQ/r² for point charges and using E = F/q for any field.
example_tasks: Calculate the electric field strength 0.3 m away from a +5 μC point charge.
At a point in space, the electric field is 1000 N/C pointing east. What force would a -2 μC charge experience at that point?
Two point charges +Q and -Q are separated by distance d. Find the electric field at the midpoint between them.

sub_topics.name: Electric Field Lines
sub_topics.short_description: Drawing and interpreting electric field line diagrams to visualize field direction and strength.
example_tasks: Draw the electric field lines around an isolated positive point charge and an isolated negative point charge.
Sketch the electric field lines for a system of two positive charges separated by some distance.
Draw the electric field lines between two parallel plates: one positive, one negative. Describe the field in the region between the plates.

sub_topics.name: Uniform Electric Fields
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding uniform fields between parallel plates where E = V/d, and motion of charges in uniform fields.
example_tasks: Two parallel plates separated by 0.05 m have a potential difference of 100 V. Calculate the electric field between them.
An electron is placed in a uniform electric field of 500 N/C. Calculate the force on the electron and its acceleration (m_e = 9.1 × 10⁻³¹ kg, e = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C).
Describe the motion of a proton released from rest in a uniform electric field pointing to the right.

sub_topics.name: Electric Potential Energy and Voltage
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding electric potential energy, electric potential (voltage), and the relationship between voltage and electric field.

sub_topics.name: Electric Potential Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding electric potential energy as energy stored in the configuration of charges, analogous to gravitational potential energy.
example_tasks: Explain the analogy between gravitational potential energy (PE = mgh) and electric potential energy for charges in an electric field.
Two positive charges are pushed closer together. What happens to the electric potential energy of the system? Explain.
A positive charge moves in the direction of an electric field. Does its electric potential energy increase or decrease? Explain.

sub_topics.name: Electric Potential (Voltage)
sub_topics.short_description: Defining electric potential (voltage) as potential energy per unit charge (V = PE/q), measured in volts (J/C).
example_tasks: A charge of 2 × 10⁻⁶ C has 0.04 J of electric potential energy at a point. Calculate the electric potential (voltage) at that point.
Explain the difference between electric potential (voltage, a scalar) and electric field (a vector quantity).
A 12 V battery provides 12 J of energy per coulomb of charge. Explain what this means in terms of electric potential difference.

sub_topics.name: Potential Difference
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding voltage as potential difference between two points, and relating it to work done moving charges.
example_tasks: A potential difference of 120 V exists between two points. How much work is done moving a +3 μC charge from the lower potential to higher potential point?
Explain why birds can sit safely on high-voltage power lines: relate to potential difference rather than absolute potential.
Calculate the kinetic energy gained by an electron accelerated through a potential difference of 1000 V.

sub_topics.name: Equipotential Lines and Surfaces
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding equipotential lines as locations of equal potential, always perpendicular to electric field lines.
example_tasks: Draw equipotential lines around an isolated positive point charge. How are they oriented relative to field lines?
Explain why no work is required to move a charge along an equipotential line.
Sketch both electric field lines and equipotential lines for two parallel plates with opposite charges.

name: Electric Circuits and Power
short_description: Understanding current, resistance, Ohm's law, series and parallel circuits, and electrical power. Students learn to analyze simple circuits and calculate circuit quantities.

sub_topics.name: Electric Current
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding current as the rate of charge flow, conventional current direction, and factors affecting current.

sub_topics.name: Defining Electric Current
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding current as charge per unit time (I = Q/t), measured in amperes (A = C/s).
example_tasks: If 10 C of charge flows through a wire in 2 seconds, calculate the current.
A current of 0.5 A flows through a light bulb. How much charge passes through the bulb in 1 minute?
Explain the relationship between the number of electrons flowing per second and the magnitude of the current in a wire.

sub_topics.name: Conventional vs. Electron Current
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that conventional current flows from positive to negative, while electrons actually flow from negative to positive.
example_tasks: Explain why we use conventional current direction (positive to negative) even though electrons flow the opposite way.
In a circuit with a battery, describe the direction of conventional current and the actual direction of electron flow.
Draw a simple circuit and indicate both conventional current direction and electron flow direction with arrows.

sub_topics.name: Current in Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that current is the same throughout a single-loop circuit due to charge conservation.
example_tasks: Explain why the current entering a light bulb must equal the current leaving it.
In a series circuit with a battery and two bulbs, explain why the current is the same through both bulbs.
A circuit has current 2 A leaving the battery. What is the current at any other point in this single-loop circuit? Explain.

sub_topics.name: Resistance and Ohm's Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding electrical resistance, applying Ohm's law, and factors affecting resistance.

sub_topics.name: Electrical Resistance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding resistance as opposition to current flow, measured in ohms (Ω), and factors affecting it.
example_tasks: Define electrical resistance and explain what it means for a material to have high resistance versus low resistance.
List factors that affect the resistance of a wire: length, cross-sectional area, material (resistivity), and temperature.
Explain why thin wires have higher resistance than thick wires of the same material and length.

sub_topics.name: Ohm's Law
sub_topics.short_description: Applying Ohm's law (V = IR) to relate voltage, current, and resistance in circuits.
example_tasks: A resistor has resistance 50 Ω and a current of 0.4 A flows through it. Calculate the voltage across the resistor.
A 12 V battery is connected to a 6 Ω resistor. Calculate the current through the resistor.
The voltage across a light bulb is 120 V and the current is 0.5 A. Calculate the resistance of the bulb.

sub_topics.name: Resistivity and Resistance Formula
sub_topics.short_description: Using R = ρL/A to calculate resistance based on material resistivity, length, and cross-sectional area.
example_tasks: A copper wire (resistivity ρ = 1.7 × 10⁻⁸ Ω·m) has length 10 m and cross-sectional area 1 × 10⁻⁶ m². Calculate its resistance.
Explain why doubling the length of a wire doubles its resistance, while doubling its cross-sectional area halves its resistance.
Compare the resistance of aluminum and copper wires of the same dimensions. Which has lower resistance and why?

sub_topics.name: Temperature and Resistance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that resistance of most conductors increases with temperature.
example_tasks: Explain why the resistance of a light bulb filament is higher when the bulb is on (hot) compared to when it's off (cool).
Describe the general relationship between temperature and resistance for metallic conductors.
A wire has resistance 10 Ω at 20°C. If its resistance increases to 12 Ω when hot, calculate the percent change in resistance.

sub_topics.name: Series Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing series circuits where components are connected in a single path, understanding current, voltage, and resistance relationships.

sub_topics.name: Series Circuit Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that in series circuits, current is constant throughout, and voltages add up to the total voltage.
example_tasks: Explain why Christmas lights wired in series all go out when one bulb burns out.
In a series circuit with a 12 V battery and two resistors, the voltages across the resistors are 5 V and 7 V. Verify that Kirchhoff's voltage law holds.
Three resistors are in series with currents I₁, I₂, and I₃. What is the relationship between these currents? Explain using charge conservation.

sub_topics.name: Equivalent Resistance in Series
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating total resistance in series using R_total = R₁ + R₂ + R₃ + ...
example_tasks: Three resistors with values 10 Ω, 20 Ω, and 30 Ω are connected in series. Calculate the equivalent resistance.
A circuit has a 12 V battery and three resistors in series: 2 Ω, 4 Ω, and 6 Ω. Calculate (a) total resistance, (b) circuit current, and (c) voltage across each resistor.
Explain why adding more resistors in series always increases the total resistance.

sub_topics.name: Voltage Division in Series Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that voltage divides among series resistors in proportion to their resistances.
example_tasks: Two resistors, 30 Ω and 60 Ω, are in series with a 90 V battery. Calculate the voltage across each resistor.
In a series circuit, a 100 Ω resistor drops 10 V. If the total voltage is 50 V, what is the resistance of the other resistor in series?
Explain why a larger resistor in a series circuit has a larger voltage drop across it.

sub_topics.name: Parallel Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing parallel circuits where components are connected across common points, understanding current division and resistance relationships.

sub_topics.name: Parallel Circuit Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that in parallel circuits, voltage is the same across all branches, and currents add up to the total current.
example_tasks: Explain why household appliances are wired in parallel: if one turns off, others still work.
In a parallel circuit with a battery and two resistors, explain why the voltage across each resistor equals the battery voltage.
Three resistors are in parallel with currents 2 A, 3 A, and 5 A. Calculate the total current from the battery.

sub_topics.name: Equivalent Resistance in Parallel
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating total resistance in parallel using 1/R_total = 1/R₁ + 1/R₂ + 1/R₃ + ...
example_tasks: Two resistors, 6 Ω and 12 Ω, are connected in parallel. Calculate the equivalent resistance.
Three identical 30 Ω resistors are connected in parallel. Calculate the total resistance.
A 12 V battery is connected to two parallel resistors: 4 Ω and 6 Ω. Calculate (a) equivalent resistance, (b) total current, and (c) current through each resistor.

sub_topics.name: Current Division in Parallel Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that current divides among parallel branches inversely proportional to their resistances.
example_tasks: Two resistors, 10 Ω and 20 Ω, are in parallel. If the total current is 6 A, calculate the current through each resistor.
Explain why more current flows through a smaller resistance in a parallel circuit.
In a parallel circuit, one branch has resistance R and current 4 A. Another branch has resistance 2R. What current flows through the second branch?

sub_topics.name: Electrical Power and Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding electrical power, using P = IV and related formulas, calculating energy consumption, and understanding power ratings.

sub_topics.name: Electrical Power
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating electrical power using P = IV, P = I²R, and P = V²/R, measured in watts (W).
example_tasks: A device operates at 120 V with current 2 A. Calculate the power consumed.
A 60 Ω resistor has 120 V across it. Calculate the power dissipated using P = V²/R.
A circuit has current 0.5 A through a 100 Ω resistor. Calculate the power dissipated using P = I²R.

sub_topics.name: Energy Consumption
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating electrical energy using E = Pt, understanding kilowatt-hours, and analyzing electricity costs.
example_tasks: A 1500 W hair dryer is used for 10 minutes. Calculate the energy consumed in joules and in kilowatt-hours.
A household uses 850 kWh of electricity in a month. If electricity costs $0.12 per kWh, calculate the monthly bill.
A 100 W light bulb runs for 8 hours per day. Calculate (a) daily energy consumption in kWh and (b) monthly cost if electricity is $0.10 per kWh.

sub_topics.name: Power Ratings and Efficiency
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding power ratings of appliances, calculating efficiency, and analyzing energy efficiency.
example_tasks: A motor is rated at 750 W. If it operates at 120 V, calculate the current it draws.
An LED bulb uses 10 W to produce the same light as a 60 W incandescent bulb. Calculate the energy savings per hour.
A power supply is 80% efficient. If it outputs 400 W, how much power does it draw from the wall outlet?

sub_topics.name: Heating Effect of Current
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Joule heating (I²R losses) and its applications in heating elements and its role in power transmission.
example_tasks: Explain why wires carrying large currents can become hot, using the formula P = I²R.
A 30 Ω heating element carries 4 A. Calculate the power dissipated as heat.
Explain why high-voltage transmission lines lose less power to heat than low-voltage lines carrying the same power (hint: P_loss = I²R and P = IV).

sub_topics.name: Circuit Analysis Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Applying Kirchhoff's laws and systematic approaches to analyze complex circuits with multiple loops and branches.

sub_topics.name: Kirchhoff's Current Law (Junction Rule)
sub_topics.short_description: Applying the junction rule: total current entering a junction equals total current leaving (conservation of charge).
example_tasks: At a junction, currents of 3 A and 2 A enter. If one current of 4 A leaves, what is the other leaving current?
Explain why Kirchhoff's current law is a consequence of conservation of charge.
In a parallel circuit junction, the total current is 10 A. If one branch carries 6 A, what current flows through the other branch?

sub_topics.name: Kirchhoff's Voltage Law (Loop Rule)
sub_topics.short_description: Applying the loop rule: sum of voltage changes around any closed loop is zero (conservation of energy).
example_tasks: A circuit loop has a 12 V battery, a 5 V drop across one resistor, and a 3 V drop across another resistor. What is the voltage drop across the third resistor?
Explain why Kirchhoff's voltage law is a consequence of conservation of energy.
Trace a loop in a circuit with a 20 V battery and three resistors with voltage drops 6 V, 8 V, and 6 V. Verify the loop rule.

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Combination Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Solving circuits with both series and parallel components using systematic reduction methods.
example_tasks: A circuit has a 24 V battery. Two 6 Ω resistors are in parallel, and this combination is in series with a 4 Ω resistor. Calculate (a) total resistance and (b) current from the battery.
Analyze a circuit with three resistors: R₁ = 10 Ω in series with a parallel combination of R₂ = 20 Ω and R₃ = 30 Ω. If the battery is 50 V, find all currents and voltages.
Describe the step-by-step process for simplifying a complex circuit with multiple series and parallel combinations to find equivalent resistance.

name: Magnetism and Electromagnetic Induction
short_description: Understanding magnetic fields, forces on moving charges and current-carrying wires, electromagnetic induction, and applications. Students learn the relationship between electricity and magnetism.

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Fields and Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding magnetic fields, magnetic poles, field lines, and forces on magnetic materials and moving charges.

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Poles and Fields
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that magnets have north and south poles, like poles repel, opposite poles attract, and magnetic field direction.
example_tasks: Describe what happens when the north pole of one magnet is brought near the north pole of another magnet.
Explain why you cannot isolate a single magnetic pole (magnetic monopoles don't exist): cutting a magnet in half creates two magnets.
Draw the magnetic field lines around a bar magnet, indicating the direction from north to south outside the magnet.

sub_topics.name: Earth's Magnetic Field
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Earth as a giant magnet, compass behavior, and the approximate alignment of Earth's magnetic and geographic poles.
example_tasks: Explain how a compass works and why it points toward Earth's magnetic north pole.
Earth's magnetic north pole is actually near the geographic South Pole. Explain this apparent contradiction.
Describe the orientation of Earth's magnetic field lines at the equator versus near the poles.

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Materials
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between ferromagnetic, paramagnetic, and diamagnetic materials based on their response to magnetic fields.
example_tasks: Identify which materials are ferromagnetic (strongly attracted to magnets): iron, wood, aluminum, nickel, copper, cobalt.
Explain why iron is attracted to magnets but wood is not, using the concept of magnetic domains.
Describe what happens to the magnetic domains in a piece of iron when it becomes magnetized.

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Field Lines
sub_topics.short_description: Drawing and interpreting magnetic field line patterns to show field direction and relative strength.
example_tasks: Sketch the magnetic field lines between two bar magnets placed with north poles facing each other.
Draw the magnetic field lines between two bar magnets placed with north pole of one facing south pole of the other.
Explain how the spacing of magnetic field lines indicates the strength of the magnetic field.

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Force on Moving Charges
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that moving charges experience forces in magnetic fields, applying the right-hand rule, and calculating magnetic forces.

sub_topics.name: Force on Moving Charge
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that a charge moving through a magnetic field experiences a force perpendicular to both velocity and field.
example_tasks: Explain why a stationary charge experiences no magnetic force, but a moving charge does.
A positive charge moves to the right through a magnetic field pointing into the page. Use the right-hand rule to determine the direction of the magnetic force.
Describe the path of a charged particle entering a uniform magnetic field perpendicular to its velocity (circular motion).

sub_topics.name: Right-Hand Rule for Magnetic Force
sub_topics.short_description: Applying the right-hand rule to determine the direction of magnetic force on a moving positive charge (F = qvB sin θ).
example_tasks: Use the right-hand rule to find the force direction on a positive charge moving north in a magnetic field pointing east.
An electron moves upward through a magnetic field pointing to the right. Determine the direction of the magnetic force (remember electrons are negative).
Explain all three directions involved in the right-hand rule: velocity (thumb), magnetic field (fingers), force (palm).

sub_topics.name: Calculating Magnetic Force
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating the magnitude of magnetic force using F = qvB when velocity is perpendicular to the field.
example_tasks: A proton (q = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C) moves at 3 × 10⁶ m/s perpendicular to a 0.5 T magnetic field. Calculate the magnetic force.
An electron moves through a magnetic field of 0.2 T with velocity 2 × 10⁷ m/s at a right angle to the field. Calculate the force magnitude.
Explain why no magnetic force acts on a charge moving parallel to the magnetic field direction.

sub_topics.name: Circular Motion in Magnetic Fields
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that a charged particle moving perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field follows a circular path.
example_tasks: Explain why a charged particle entering a magnetic field perpendicular to its velocity moves in a circle.
Describe how the magnetic force provides the centripetal force for circular motion: F_magnetic = F_centripetal, or qvB = mv²/r.
Particle accelerators use magnetic fields to bend particle paths. Explain how the radius of curvature depends on the particle's speed, mass, and charge.

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Force on Current-Carrying Wires
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that current-carrying wires experience forces in magnetic fields, calculating forces, and understanding motor principles.

sub_topics.name: Force on Current-Carrying Wire
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that a wire carrying current through a magnetic field experiences a force, using F = BIL.
example_tasks: Explain why a current-carrying wire experiences a force in a magnetic field, relating to the force on moving charges.
A 0.5 m wire carries 10 A perpendicular to a 0.4 T magnetic field. Calculate the force on the wire.
Use the right-hand rule to determine the force direction on a wire carrying current to the right in a magnetic field pointing out of the page.

sub_topics.name: Forces Between Parallel Currents
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that parallel wires carrying current in the same direction attract, opposite directions repel.
example_tasks: Two parallel wires carry currents in the same direction. Explain why they attract each other using magnetic fields.
Describe the force between two parallel wires carrying currents in opposite directions.
Explain how the definition of the ampere is based on the force between two parallel current-carrying wires.

sub_topics.name: Electric Motors (Basic Principle)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how electric motors use magnetic forces on current-carrying coils to produce rotation.
example_tasks: Describe the basic principle of an electric motor: a current-carrying loop in a magnetic field experiences a torque.
Explain the role of a commutator in a DC motor: reversing current direction each half-turn to maintain continuous rotation.
A rectangular coil carrying current is placed in a magnetic field. Describe how the forces on opposite sides of the coil produce a torque.

sub_topics.name: Sources of Magnetic Fields
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that moving charges and electric currents create magnetic fields, visualizing fields around wires and coils.

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Field from Straight Wire
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that a straight current-carrying wire creates circular magnetic field lines around it.
example_tasks: Describe the shape and direction of magnetic field lines around a long straight wire carrying current.
Use the right-hand rule for a current-carrying wire: thumb points in current direction, fingers curl in field direction.
Explain how a compass placed near a current-carrying wire will align with the magnetic field created by the current.

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Field from Current Loop
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that a current loop creates a magnetic field similar to a bar magnet with north and south poles.
example_tasks: Sketch the magnetic field lines around a single circular loop of wire carrying current.
Identify which side of a current loop acts as a north pole and which as a south pole using the right-hand rule.
Explain why a current loop (or coil) creates a stronger, more focused magnetic field than a straight wire.

sub_topics.name: Electromagnets
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding electromagnets as coils wrapped around iron cores, controlled by current, and their applications.
example_tasks: Explain how an electromagnet differs from a permanent magnet and the advantages of each.
Describe three ways to increase the strength of an electromagnet: increase current, add more coil turns, use an iron core.
List three applications of electromagnets (e.g., electric bells, cranes for lifting scrap metal, MRI machines) and explain one in detail.

sub_topics.name: Electromagnetic Induction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Faraday's law of induction, induced EMF and current, Lenz's law, and applications in generators and transformers.

sub_topics.name: Faraday's Law of Induction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that a changing magnetic flux through a coil induces an EMF (voltage), basis for generators.
example_tasks: Explain Faraday's discovery: moving a magnet through a coil induces a current in the coil.
List three ways to induce a current in a coil: move a magnet toward/away from it, move the coil in a magnetic field, change the field strength.
Describe why moving a magnet slowly versus quickly through a coil affects the magnitude of the induced current.

sub_topics.name: Lenz's Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that the direction of induced current opposes the change in magnetic flux (conservation of energy).
example_tasks: A magnet's north pole approaches a coil. Use Lenz's law to determine the direction of induced current (the coil acts to repel the magnet).
Explain why Lenz's law is consistent with conservation of energy: induced effects oppose the change causing them.
A magnet is pulled away from a coil. Predict whether the coil attracts or repels the magnet using Lenz's law.

sub_topics.name: Electric Generators
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how generators convert mechanical energy to electrical energy using electromagnetic induction.
example_tasks: Describe the basic operation of an electric generator: rotating a coil in a magnetic field induces alternating current.
Explain the difference between AC and DC generators in terms of the type of current produced.
Compare generators and motors: generators convert mechanical to electrical energy, motors convert electrical to mechanical energy.

sub_topics.name: Transformers (Introduction)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that transformers change AC voltage using electromagnetic induction between primary and secondary coils.
example_tasks: Explain the basic principle of a transformer: changing current in primary coil induces voltage in secondary coil via changing magnetic flux.
A step-up transformer increases voltage. Describe the relationship between the number of turns in primary versus secondary coils.
Explain why transformers only work with AC voltage, not DC voltage (DC doesn't produce a changing magnetic field).

name: Light and Geometric Optics
short_description: Understanding the nature of light, reflection, refraction, lenses, mirrors, and optical instruments. Students learn to apply ray diagrams and equations to analyze image formation.

sub_topics.name: Nature of Light
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding light as electromagnetic waves, the electromagnetic spectrum, speed of light, and basic wave-particle duality.

sub_topics.name: Light as Electromagnetic Waves
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding light as electromagnetic waves that don't require a medium, traveling at speed c = 3 × 10⁸ m/s in vacuum.
example_tasks: Explain how light differs from sound: light is electromagnetic (no medium needed), sound is mechanical (requires medium).
Calculate the time for light to travel from the Sun to Earth (distance ≈ 1.5 × 10¹¹ m, c = 3 × 10⁸ m/s).
Describe the wave characteristics of light: wavelength, frequency, and the relationship c = fλ.

sub_topics.name: The Electromagnetic Spectrum
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the electromagnetic spectrum from radio waves to gamma rays, with visible light as a small portion.
example_tasks: List the regions of the electromagnetic spectrum in order of increasing frequency: radio, microwave, infrared, visible, ultraviolet, X-rays, gamma rays.
Visible light ranges from about 400 nm (violet) to 700 nm (red). Calculate the frequency range of visible light.
Explain why different regions of the spectrum have different properties and uses (e.g., X-rays penetrate tissue, radio waves for communication).

sub_topics.name: The Visible Spectrum
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that white light is composed of all colors, and color corresponds to wavelength/frequency.
example_tasks: Explain why red light has the longest wavelength in the visible spectrum and violet has the shortest.
Describe what happens when white light passes through a prism: it separates into colors due to different wavelengths refracting differently.
List the colors of the visible spectrum in order from longest to shortest wavelength: ROYGBIV.

sub_topics.name: Reflection of Light
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the law of reflection, types of reflection (specular and diffuse), and image formation by plane mirrors.

sub_topics.name: Law of Reflection
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that angle of incidence equals angle of reflection, both measured from the normal to the surface.
example_tasks: A light ray strikes a mirror at 30° from the normal. What is the angle of reflection measured from the normal?
Draw a diagram showing incident ray, reflected ray, and normal for a light ray hitting a flat mirror at 45°.
Explain why the angles are measured from the normal (perpendicular) to the surface rather than from the surface itself.

sub_topics.name: Specular vs. Diffuse Reflection
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between specular reflection (smooth surfaces, clear images) and diffuse reflection (rough surfaces, scattered light).
example_tasks: Explain why you can see your reflection clearly in a calm lake (specular) but not in a choppy lake (diffuse).
Compare reflection from a polished metal surface versus a white wall. Which is specular and which is diffuse?
Draw diagrams showing parallel incident rays reflecting from (a) a smooth mirror and (b) a rough surface.

sub_topics.name: Plane Mirrors
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding image formation by plane mirrors: images are virtual, upright, same size, and appear as far behind mirror as object is in front.
example_tasks: An object is placed 2 m in front of a plane mirror. Describe the location, size, and orientation of the image.
Draw a ray diagram showing how an image forms in a plane mirror, tracing at least two rays from an object point.
Explain the difference between a real image (formed by actual light rays) and a virtual image (appears to be behind the mirror).

sub_topics.name: Refraction of Light
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding refraction as bending of light when passing between media, Snell's law, and applications including total internal reflection.

sub_topics.name: Refraction Concept
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that light bends when entering a different medium due to change in speed, toward the normal when slowing, away when speeding up.
example_tasks: Explain why a straw appears bent when placed in a glass of water, using the concept of refraction.
Light travels from air into water. Does it bend toward or away from the normal? Explain using the change in speed.
Describe what happens to the speed, wavelength, and frequency of light as it enters a denser medium.

sub_topics.name: Snell's Law
sub_topics.short_description: Applying Snell's law (n₁ sin θ₁ = n₂ sin θ₂) to calculate angles of refraction, understanding index of refraction.
example_tasks: Light travels from air (n = 1.0) into glass (n = 1.5) at an incident angle of 30°. Calculate the angle of refraction using Snell's law.
The index of refraction of water is 1.33. If light enters water at 45° from air, calculate the refraction angle.
Explain what the index of refraction means: the ratio of speed of light in vacuum to speed in the medium.

sub_topics.name: Total Internal Reflection
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding critical angle and total internal reflection when light travels from denser to less dense medium at angles beyond critical.
example_tasks: Explain why diamonds sparkle: total internal reflection keeps light bouncing inside due to the large critical angle.
Calculate the critical angle for light traveling from glass (n = 1.5) to air (n = 1.0) using sin θ_c = n₂/n₁.
Describe how fiber optic cables use total internal reflection to transmit light signals over long distances.

sub_topics.name: Dispersion of Light
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that different wavelengths refract by different amounts, causing white light to separate into colors.
example_tasks: Explain how a prism creates a rainbow by separating white light into its component colors (dispersion).
Which color bends more when passing through a prism: red or blue? Explain using the concept of index of refraction varying with wavelength.
Describe how rainbows form in nature using refraction, dispersion, and reflection of sunlight in water droplets.

sub_topics.name: Curved Mirrors
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding concave and convex mirrors, ray diagrams, mirror equations, and image characteristics.

sub_topics.name: Concave Mirrors
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding concave (converging) mirrors that can form real or virtual images depending on object position relative to focal point.
example_tasks: Define the focal point and focal length of a concave mirror. Explain how parallel rays converge at the focal point.
Draw a ray diagram for an object placed beyond the focal point of a concave mirror, showing the real, inverted image.
Describe what happens to the image as an object moves from far away toward the focal point of a concave mirror.

sub_topics.name: Convex Mirrors
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding convex (diverging) mirrors that always form virtual, upright, reduced images behind the mirror.
example_tasks: Explain why convex mirrors are used as security mirrors in stores: they provide a wide field of view.
Draw a ray diagram for an object in front of a convex mirror, showing the virtual, upright, reduced image.
Compare the images formed by concave and convex mirrors in terms of size, orientation, and real vs. virtual.

sub_topics.name: Mirror Equation
sub_topics.short_description: Using the mirror equation 1/f = 1/d_o + 1/d_i and magnification M = -d_i/d_o to solve quantitative problems.
example_tasks: A concave mirror has focal length 10 cm. An object is placed 30 cm from the mirror. Calculate the image distance and magnification.
An object 5 cm tall is placed 15 cm from a concave mirror with focal length 10 cm. Calculate (a) image distance, (b) image height, (c) whether image is real or virtual.
Explain the sign conventions: focal length positive for concave mirrors, image distance positive for real images, negative for virtual.

sub_topics.name: Lenses
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding converging and diverging lenses, ray diagrams, lens equations, and applications in optical instruments.

sub_topics.name: Converging (Convex) Lenses
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding convex lenses that bring parallel rays to a focus, can form real or virtual images depending on object position.
example_tasks: Draw a ray diagram for an object placed beyond 2F (twice the focal length) of a converging lens, showing the real, inverted, reduced image.
Describe the three principal rays used in ray diagrams for lenses: parallel ray, focal ray, and central ray.
An object is placed between the focal point and a converging lens. Describe the image formed: virtual, upright, magnified (magnifying glass).

sub_topics.name: Diverging (Concave) Lenses
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding concave lenses that spread out parallel rays, always forming virtual, upright, reduced images.
example_tasks: Draw a ray diagram for an object in front of a diverging lens, showing the virtual, upright, reduced image.
Explain why diverging lenses are used to correct nearsightedness (myopia): they spread out light rays before they enter the eye.
Compare the images formed by converging and diverging lenses in terms of real vs. virtual, magnification, and orientation.

sub_topics.name: Thin Lens Equation
sub_topics.short_description: Using 1/f = 1/d_o + 1/d_i and M = -d_i/d_o to solve lens problems, understanding sign conventions.
example_tasks: A converging lens has focal length 20 cm. An object is placed 60 cm from the lens. Calculate the image distance and magnification.
An object 3 cm tall is placed 10 cm from a converging lens with focal length 15 cm. Calculate (a) image distance, (b) image height, (c) whether the image is real or virtual.
Explain the sign conventions for lenses: focal length positive for converging, negative for diverging; image distance positive for real images.

sub_topics.name: Optical Instruments
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how lenses are used in magnifying glasses, microscopes, telescopes, cameras, and the human eye.
example_tasks: Explain how a simple magnifying glass works: object placed within focal length creates enlarged virtual image.
Describe the basic function of a compound microscope: objective lens creates real image, which is magnified by eyepiece lens.
Compare the designs of refracting telescopes and microscopes in terms of lens arrangement and purpose (viewing distant vs. small objects).

sub_topics.name: The Human Eye and Vision
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the structure and function of the eye, focusing mechanism (accommodation), and common vision defects and corrections.

sub_topics.name: Eye Structure and Function
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the parts of the eye (cornea, lens, retina) and how the eye focuses light to form images on the retina.
example_tasks: Describe the path of light through the eye: cornea → aqueous humor → lens → vitreous humor → retina.
Explain the roles of the cornea and lens in focusing light, and the retina in detecting images.
Describe accommodation: how the eye changes focus by changing lens shape (thick for near objects, thin for distant objects).

sub_topics.name: Common Vision Defects
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding nearsightedness (myopia), farsightedness (hyperopia), and astigmatism in terms of image formation.
example_tasks: Explain nearsightedness (myopia): eye focuses distant objects in front of the retina. What type of lens corrects this?
Explain farsightedness (hyperopia): eye focuses close objects behind the retina. What type of lens corrects this?
Describe astigmatism as caused by irregular curvature of the cornea or lens, resulting in blurred vision.

sub_topics.name: Corrective Lenses
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how diverging lenses correct nearsightedness and converging lenses correct farsightedness.
example_tasks: A person with myopia needs glasses with focal length -50 cm. Explain how these diverging lenses help them see distant objects clearly.
Explain why reading glasses (converging lenses) help people with presbyopia (age-related farsightedness) see nearby objects.
Compare the optical prescriptions for myopia (negative diopters) and hyperopia (positive diopters).

name: Advanced Mechanics and Dynamics
short_description: Advanced application of Newton's laws to complex force systems, non-uniform circular motion, advanced energy methods, and sophisticated problem-solving in dynamics. Students develop deeper analytical skills in mechanics.

sub_topics.name: Forces in Equilibrium (Advanced)
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing complex equilibrium situations involving multiple forces, tension in multiple ropes, and three-dimensional force systems.

sub_topics.name: Static Equilibrium Conditions
sub_topics.short_description: Applying both ΣF = 0 and Στ = 0 for complete static equilibrium in two and three dimensions.
example_tasks: A beam is supported by a cable and a hinge. Given the beam's weight and dimensions, calculate the tension in the cable and forces at the hinge using both force and torque equilibrium.
Explain why both translational equilibrium (ΣF = 0) and rotational equilibrium (Στ = 0) are necessary for complete static equilibrium.
A sign hangs from a rod attached to a wall at an angle. Calculate all forces and torques to determine if the system is in equilibrium.

sub_topics.name: Center of Mass and Center of Gravity
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating center of mass for systems of particles and extended objects, understanding stability conditions.
example_tasks: Three masses (2 kg at x=0, 3 kg at x=4 m, 5 kg at x=7 m) lie on a line. Calculate the center of mass position.
Explain why a person carrying a heavy backpack leans forward to maintain balance, using the concept of center of gravity.
A uniform L-shaped object is made from two rods. Calculate the center of mass location and determine where to support it for balance.

sub_topics.name: Complex Tension Problems
sub_topics.short_description: Solving problems with multiple cables, pulleys, and tension forces in different configurations.
example_tasks: A mass hangs from two cables making angles 30° and 60° with the ceiling. Calculate the tension in each cable.
Analyze a system of pulleys where a mass hangs from a combination of fixed and movable pulleys. Calculate the force needed to lift the mass.
A traffic light hangs from two cables attached to a single point. If the cables make equal angles θ with the horizontal and the light has mass M, find the tension as a function of θ.

sub_topics.name: Non-Uniform Circular Motion
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing circular motion with changing speed, understanding tangential and centripetal acceleration components, and banking problems.

sub_topics.name: Tangential and Centripetal Acceleration
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that objects in non-uniform circular motion have both tangential acceleration (changing speed) and centripetal acceleration (changing direction).
example_tasks: A car speeds up while rounding a curve. Draw vectors showing both the tangential acceleration (along velocity) and centripetal acceleration (toward center).
Calculate the magnitude of total acceleration for an object moving in a circle of radius 5 m with speed 10 m/s that's increasing at 2 m/s².
Explain the difference between uniform circular motion (only centripetal acceleration) and non-uniform circular motion (both components).

sub_topics.name: Vertical Circular Motion
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing motion in vertical circles, calculating minimum speeds at top and bottom, and understanding tension/normal force variations.
example_tasks: A ball on a string moves in a vertical circle of radius 1 m. Calculate the minimum speed at the top for the string to remain taut.
Analyze a roller coaster loop: calculate the normal force on a rider at the top and bottom if the loop has radius 20 m and speed 25 m/s.
A bucket of water is swung in a vertical circle. Explain why the water doesn't fall out at the top if swung fast enough, using force analysis.

sub_topics.name: Banked Curves
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing motion on banked curves, calculating ideal banking angles, and understanding friction's role at different speeds.
example_tasks: Derive the formula for ideal banking angle (tan θ = v²/rg) where no friction is needed for a car to navigate a curve.
