A curved highway ramp has radius 100 m and is banked at 15°. Calculate the speed at which a car can take the curve with no friction.
Explain why banked curves allow higher safe speeds than flat curves, using free-body diagrams and force components.

sub_topics.name: Conical Pendulum
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the motion of a conical pendulum where the bob moves in a horizontal circle.
example_tasks: A conical pendulum has a string of length 2 m making an angle 30° with the vertical. Calculate the speed of the bob and the period of rotation.
Derive expressions for the tension in the string and the radius of the circular path for a conical pendulum in terms of length L, angle θ, and mass m.
Compare the forces acting on a simple pendulum at its lowest point to those on a conical pendulum.

sub_topics.name: Advanced Energy Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Using energy methods to solve complex problems, understanding conservative and non-conservative forces, and applying work-energy theorem in multiple dimensions.

sub_topics.name: Conservative and Non-Conservative Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between conservative forces (path-independent work) and non-conservative forces (path-dependent work).
example_tasks: Explain why gravitational and spring forces are conservative while friction and air resistance are non-conservative.
Calculate the work done by gravity on an object moving from point A to point B along two different paths. Show that the work is path-independent.
A box is pushed up a rough incline. Identify which forces are conservative and which are non-conservative, explaining the difference.

sub_topics.name: Mechanical Energy with Non-Conservative Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Applying energy conservation when non-conservative forces are present: E_initial + W_nc = E_final.
example_tasks: A 5 kg block slides down a 10 m ramp inclined at 30° with coefficient of friction 0.2. Use energy methods to find its speed at the bottom.
A pendulum bob is released from height h but only reaches height 0.9h on the other side due to air resistance. Calculate the energy lost.
Compare solving a friction problem using (a) Newton's laws with kinematics and (b) energy methods. Show they give the same answer.

sub_topics.name: Power in Rotational Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating power in rotating systems using P = τω and relating to translational power.
example_tasks: An engine delivers 100 N·m of torque while rotating at 3000 rpm. Calculate the power output in watts.
A wheel accelerates from rest with constant angular acceleration 2 rad/s². If the applied torque is 50 N·m, calculate the power at t = 5 s.
Compare the power required to lift a mass vertically at constant speed versus rotating it in a horizontal circle at the same tangential speed.

sub_topics.name: Potential Energy Diagrams
sub_topics.short_description: Interpreting and using potential energy versus position diagrams to analyze motion, equilibrium points, and turning points.
example_tasks: Given a potential energy curve U(x), identify stable equilibrium points, unstable equilibrium points, and regions where motion is possible for a given total energy.
Sketch the potential energy diagram for a mass on a spring, and indicate the kinetic energy at different positions for a given total energy.
From a U(x) graph, explain how to find the force at any position using F = -dU/dx (slope of the curve).

sub_topics.name: Systems of Particles and Advanced Collisions
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing center of mass motion, advanced collision problems, coefficient of restitution, and variable mass systems.

sub_topics.name: Center of Mass Motion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that the center of mass of a system moves as if all mass were concentrated there with net external force applied.
example_tasks: Two astronauts (masses 60 kg and 80 kg) push off each other in space. If the lighter one moves at 2 m/s, find the velocity of the center of mass.
A firecracker explodes into three fragments. Prove that the center of mass continues moving with the original velocity.
Calculate the position and velocity of the center of mass for a system of three particles with given positions, velocities, and masses.

sub_topics.name: Advanced Elastic Collision Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Solving elastic collision problems in one and two dimensions using both momentum and energy conservation.
example_tasks: Two billiard balls collide elastically at a glancing angle. Given initial velocities, calculate final velocities using momentum conservation in both x and y directions plus energy conservation.
Derive the final velocity formulas for a 1D elastic collision between masses m₁ and m₂ with initial velocities v₁ and v₂.
A moving ball collides elastically with an identical stationary ball. Show that they move off at 90° to each other.

sub_topics.name: Coefficient of Restitution (Advanced)
sub_topics.short_description: Using coefficient of restitution (e) to solve collision problems, relating to energy loss in collisions.
example_tasks: A ball with e = 0.8 is dropped from height 2 m. Calculate the height after the first, second, and third bounces.
Two carts collide with coefficient of restitution 0.6. Given initial velocities, calculate final velocities using e = (v₂f - v₁f)/(v₁i - v₂i).
Derive the relationship between coefficient of restitution and the fraction of kinetic energy lost in a collision.

sub_topics.name: Variable Mass Systems (Introduction)
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing systems where mass changes with time, such as rockets, using thrust equation F = v_exhaust(dm/dt).
example_tasks: A rocket expels exhaust at 3000 m/s at a rate of 100 kg/s. Calculate the thrust force on the rocket.
Explain rocket propulsion in terms of momentum conservation: the rocket gains forward momentum as exhaust gases gain backward momentum.
A conveyor belt drops sand onto a moving cart at constant rate. Analyze the forces required to maintain constant velocity.

sub_topics.name: Rotational Dynamics (Advanced)
sub_topics.short_description: Advanced analysis of rotational motion including rolling motion, angular momentum conservation, and complex torque problems.

sub_topics.name: Rolling Motion
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing rolling without slipping, relating linear and angular quantities, and understanding kinetic energy in rolling objects.
example_tasks: A sphere rolls down an incline without slipping. Derive its acceleration using both translational and rotational dynamics.
Calculate the total kinetic energy of a rolling cylinder: KE_total = ½mv² + ½Iω². Show that for rolling without slipping, v = ωr.
Compare the speeds at the bottom of an incline for objects that slide (no rotation) versus roll: sphere, cylinder, and hoop.

sub_topics.name: Angular Momentum
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding angular momentum L = Iω for rotating objects and L = mvr for point masses, and the relationship τ = dL/dt.
example_tasks: Calculate the angular momentum of a disk (mass 5 kg, radius 0.4 m) rotating at 20 rad/s about its center.
A figure skater spins with arms extended at 1 rev/s. When arms are pulled in, the moment of inertia decreases by factor of 2. Find the new angular velocity.
Show that τ = dL/dt is the rotational analog of F = dp/dt, relating torque to rate of change of angular momentum.

sub_topics.name: Conservation of Angular Momentum
sub_topics.short_description: Applying conservation of angular momentum when net external torque is zero, analyzing spinning systems and collisions.
example_tasks: A spinning disk (I₁, ω₁) is dropped onto a stationary disk (I₂) on the same axle. Find the final angular velocity using angular momentum conservation.
A person stands on a rotating platform holding weights. Explain quantitatively how pulling the weights inward increases rotation rate.
A merry-go-round rotates at 0.5 rev/s with moment of inertia 500 kg·m². A 50 kg child jumps on at the edge (radius 2 m). Find the new angular velocity.

sub_topics.name: Precession and Gyroscopes (Introduction)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding gyroscopic motion and precession as changes in angular momentum direction due to applied torques.
example_tasks: Explain why a spinning top precesses rather than falling over immediately when tilted.
Describe the direction of precession for a spinning wheel when a torque is applied perpendicular to its angular momentum vector.
Qualitatively explain how gyroscopes are used for navigation and stabilization in aircraft and spacecraft.

name: Oscillations and Simple Harmonic Motion
short_description: Understanding periodic motion, simple harmonic motion in springs and pendulums, energy in oscillating systems, damped and driven oscillations, and resonance phenomena. Students learn to describe oscillations mathematically.

sub_topics.name: Characteristics of Periodic Motion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding amplitude, period, frequency, and phase in oscillatory motion, and graphical representations.

sub_topics.name: Describing Oscillations
sub_topics.short_description: Defining amplitude as maximum displacement, period as time for one cycle, and frequency as cycles per second.
example_tasks: A mass on a spring oscillates between +10 cm and -10 cm, completing 5 cycles in 2 seconds. Determine the amplitude, period, and frequency.
Explain the relationship between period and frequency (T = 1/f) using a specific oscillating system as an example.
Sketch a position vs. time graph for simple harmonic motion, labeling amplitude, period, and equilibrium position.

sub_topics.name: Restoring Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that oscillations require a restoring force proportional to displacement and directed toward equilibrium: F = -kx.
example_tasks: Explain why a mass on a spring oscillates: the spring force acts as a restoring force proportional to displacement.
Describe the restoring force for a simple pendulum at small angles, showing it's approximately proportional to displacement.
Compare the restoring forces in a mass-spring system and a pendulum, discussing when each exhibits simple harmonic motion.

sub_topics.name: Graphical Analysis of SHM
sub_topics.short_description: Interpreting and creating position, velocity, and acceleration vs. time graphs for simple harmonic motion.
example_tasks: Given a position vs. time graph for SHM, sketch the corresponding velocity and acceleration graphs, noting phase relationships.
On a position vs. time graph for SHM, identify points where: (a) velocity is maximum, (b) acceleration is maximum, (c) both are zero.
Explain why position and acceleration are 180° out of phase in SHM while position and velocity are 90° out of phase.

sub_topics.name: Mass-Spring Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing oscillations of masses on springs, calculating period and frequency, and understanding the relationship between spring constant and oscillation properties.

sub_topics.name: Spring Force and Hooke's Law
sub_topics.short_description: Applying Hooke's law F = -kx and understanding spring constant as a measure of stiffness.
example_tasks: A spring stretches 5 cm when a 2 kg mass hangs from it. Calculate the spring constant.
Two springs with constants k₁ = 100 N/m and k₂ = 200 N/m are stretched by the same amount. Compare the forces required.
Explain the negative sign in Hooke's law: the spring force opposes displacement from equilibrium.

sub_topics.name: Period and Frequency of Mass-Spring System
sub_topics.short_description: Using T = 2π√(m/k) to calculate period and frequency of oscillation for a mass on a spring.
example_tasks: A 0.5 kg mass on a spring with k = 50 N/m oscillates. Calculate the period and frequency.
If the mass on a spring is quadrupled, by what factor does the period change? Explain using T = 2π√(m/k).
Two different masses oscillate on identical springs. If mass 1 has twice the period of mass 2, what is the ratio of their masses?

sub_topics.name: Energy in Mass-Spring Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the interchange between kinetic and potential energy in oscillating spring systems, with total mechanical energy constant.
example_tasks: A 2 kg mass on a spring (k = 100 N/m) has amplitude 0.3 m. Calculate (a) maximum potential energy, (b) maximum kinetic energy, (c) maximum speed.
Sketch potential energy, kinetic energy, and total energy vs. position for one complete oscillation of a mass-spring system.
At what positions in its oscillation does a mass on a spring have equal kinetic and potential energies? Calculate these positions in terms of amplitude.

sub_topics.name: Vertical Spring Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing vertical mass-spring systems where gravity affects equilibrium position but not the period.
example_tasks: Explain why the period of a vertical spring-mass system is the same as a horizontal one, even though gravity affects the equilibrium position.
A mass hangs from a vertical spring and stretches it 10 cm to equilibrium. If pulled down 5 cm more and released, calculate the amplitude and period of oscillation.
Derive that the new equilibrium position for a mass on a vertical spring is at y₀ = mg/k below the natural length.

sub_topics.name: Pendulums
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing simple pendulums and physical pendulums, calculating periods, and understanding small angle approximations.

sub_topics.name: Simple Pendulum
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the simple pendulum using T = 2π√(L/g) for small angles, understanding length and gravity dependence.
example_tasks: A simple pendulum has length 1 m. Calculate its period on Earth (g = 9.8 m/s²) and on the Moon (g = 1.6 m/s²).
If the length of a pendulum is quadrupled, by what factor does the period change?
Explain why the period of a simple pendulum is independent of mass but depends on length and gravitational field strength.

sub_topics.name: Small Angle Approximation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that the simple pendulum formula is valid only for small angles (typically < 15°) where sin θ ≈ θ.
example_tasks: Explain why T = 2π√(L/g) is an approximation that's valid only for small amplitude oscillations of a pendulum.
Compare the periods of two identical pendulums, one swinging with 5° amplitude and another with 30° amplitude. Which formula gives more accurate results?
Show that for small angles θ (in radians), sin θ ≈ θ, and explain how this leads to simple harmonic motion for pendulums.

sub_topics.name: Energy in Pendulum Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing energy transformations in pendulums between gravitational potential energy and kinetic energy.
example_tasks: A pendulum bob of mass 0.5 kg is released from a height 0.2 m above its lowest point. Calculate its maximum speed at the bottom.
Sketch graphs of potential energy, kinetic energy, and total energy vs. angle for one complete oscillation of a pendulum.
At what angle during its swing does a pendulum have equal kinetic and potential energies (measuring from the lowest point)?

sub_topics.name: Physical Pendulum (Introduction)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that any rigid body can act as a pendulum, with period depending on moment of inertia and distance to pivot.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between a simple pendulum (point mass on string) and a physical pendulum (extended object).
A uniform rod of length L is pivoted at one end and swings as a pendulum. Qualitatively compare its period to a simple pendulum of length L.
Describe real-world examples of physical pendulums, such as a swinging leg or a baseball bat pivoting at the handle.

sub_topics.name: Mathematical Description of SHM
sub_topics.short_description: Using sinusoidal functions to describe position, velocity, and acceleration in SHM, understanding phase constants and angular frequency.

sub_topics.name: Position Equation for SHM
sub_topics.short_description: Using x(t) = A cos(ωt + φ) or x(t) = A sin(ωt + φ) to describe position as a function of time.
example_tasks: A mass oscillates with amplitude 0.1 m and angular frequency 5 rad/s. Write the position equation if it starts at maximum displacement.
Given x(t) = 0.2 cos(4πt), determine the amplitude, angular frequency, frequency, and period of oscillation.
Explain the meaning of the phase constant φ in the equation x(t) = A cos(ωt + φ), and how it depends on initial conditions.

sub_topics.name: Velocity and Acceleration in SHM
sub_topics.short_description: Deriving velocity v(t) = -Aω sin(ωt + φ) and acceleration a(t) = -Aω² cos(ωt + φ) through differentiation.
example_tasks: Given x(t) = 0.5 cos(3t), derive the velocity and acceleration functions by differentiation.
For an oscillator with x(t) = A cos(ωt), find expressions for maximum velocity and maximum acceleration in terms of A and ω.
Show that acceleration is always proportional to displacement but opposite in direction: a = -ω²x.

sub_topics.name: Angular Frequency
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding angular frequency ω = 2πf = 2π/T and its relationship to the physical properties of the system.
example_tasks: A system oscillates with period 0.5 s. Calculate the angular frequency ω.
For a mass-spring system, show that ω = √(k/m). For a simple pendulum, show that ω = √(g/L).
Explain why angular frequency is measured in rad/s and how it relates to ordinary frequency (Hz).

sub_topics.name: Phase Relationships in SHM
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding phase differences between position, velocity, and acceleration in SHM.
example_tasks: Show that velocity leads position by 90° (π/2 radians) in phase: when position is maximum, velocity is zero, and vice versa.
Demonstrate that acceleration is 180° out of phase with position: when position is maximum positive, acceleration is maximum negative.
Graph position, velocity, and acceleration on the same axes for one complete cycle, showing their phase relationships.

sub_topics.name: Damped and Driven Oscillations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding damping forces that cause amplitude to decrease, driven oscillations with external periodic forces, and resonance phenomena.

sub_topics.name: Damped Oscillations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that friction and air resistance cause damping, reducing amplitude exponentially over time while slightly increasing period.
example_tasks: Describe the motion of a damped oscillator: amplitude decreases exponentially, but the system continues to oscillate (if underdamped).
Sketch graphs comparing undamped, underdamped, critically damped, and overdamped oscillations.
Give examples of damped oscillations in real life: car shock absorbers, clock pendulums, diving boards after a dive.

sub_topics.name: Quality Factor
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the quality factor Q as a measure of how well an oscillator maintains oscillations despite damping.
example_tasks: Explain what a high Q value means: the oscillator loses energy slowly and maintains oscillations for many cycles.
Compare the Q factors of a tuning fork (high Q, rings for a long time) and a heavily damped door closer (low Q, returns to equilibrium quickly).
Describe how Q relates to the sharpness of resonance peaks: higher Q means sharper, taller resonance peaks.

sub_topics.name: Driven Oscillations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that external periodic forces can drive oscillations, with amplitude depending on the driving frequency relative to natural frequency.
example_tasks: Explain what happens when a system is driven at a frequency different from its natural frequency: it oscillates at the driving frequency with varying amplitude.
Describe steady-state motion of a driven oscillator: after transients die away, it oscillates at the driving frequency.
Give examples of driven oscillations: pushing someone on a swing, forcing a tuning fork with sound waves, AC circuits.

sub_topics.name: Resonance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that amplitude is maximized when driving frequency matches natural frequency, with applications and hazards of resonance.
example_tasks: Explain resonance: when driving frequency equals natural frequency, energy transfer is most efficient and amplitude grows large.
Describe the Tacoma Narrows Bridge collapse (1940) as an example of destructive resonance caused by wind-driven oscillations.
Give beneficial applications of resonance: tuning a radio to match broadcast frequency, using resonance in musical instruments, MRI machines.

name: Fluid Mechanics
short_description: Understanding pressure in fluids, buoyancy, continuity equation, Bernoulli's equation, and applications to fluid flow. Students learn to analyze static and dynamic fluid systems.

sub_topics.name: Pressure in Fluids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding pressure as force per unit area, Pascal's principle, and pressure variation with depth in static fluids.

sub_topics.name: Defining Pressure
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding pressure as P = F/A, measured in pascals (Pa = N/m²), and atmospheric pressure at sea level.
example_tasks: Calculate the pressure exerted by a 50 kg person standing on one foot with area 0.02 m².
Atmospheric pressure at sea level is approximately 101,325 Pa (1 atm). Express this in kPa and in units of pounds per square inch (psi).
Explain why a sharp knife cuts more easily than a dull one, using the concept of pressure.

sub_topics.name: Pressure and Depth
sub_topics.short_description: Using P = P₀ + ρgh to calculate pressure at depth in a fluid, understanding hydrostatic pressure.
example_tasks: Calculate the water pressure at a depth of 50 m in a lake (ρ_water = 1000 kg/m³, g = 10 m/s²). Include atmospheric pressure.
A submarine dives to 200 m depth in seawater (ρ = 1025 kg/m³). Calculate the total pressure on its hull.
Explain why dams are built thicker at the bottom than at the top, using the concept of pressure increasing with depth.

sub_topics.name: Pascal's Principle
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that pressure applied to an enclosed fluid is transmitted undiminished throughout the fluid.
example_tasks: Explain how hydraulic lifts work: small force on small piston creates large force on large piston, using Pascal's principle.
A hydraulic press has piston areas of 0.01 m² and 0.2 m². If 100 N is applied to the small piston, calculate the force on the large piston.
Describe other applications of Pascal's principle: car brakes, hydraulic jacks, dentist chairs.

sub_topics.name: Measuring Pressure
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding barometers for measuring atmospheric pressure and manometers for measuring pressure differences.
example_tasks: Explain how a mercury barometer works: atmospheric pressure supports a column of mercury ~760 mm high at sea level.
A U-tube manometer shows a height difference of 15 cm of water between the two arms. Calculate the pressure difference.
Convert between different pressure units: atmospheres (atm), pascals (Pa), millimeters of mercury (mmHg), and torr.

sub_topics.name: Buoyancy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Archimedes' principle, calculating buoyant forces, and analyzing floating and sinking objects.

sub_topics.name: Archimedes' Principle
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that buoyant force equals the weight of fluid displaced: F_b = ρ_fluid × V_displaced × g.
example_tasks: A rock with volume 0.002 m³ is submerged in water. Calculate the buoyant force on it.
Explain why ships made of steel float even though steel is denser than water, using Archimedes' principle.
A 10 kg object is fully submerged in water and experiences a buoyant force of 80 N. Calculate the object's volume and density.

sub_topics.name: Floating and Sinking
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding conditions for floating (ρ_object < ρ_fluid) and sinking (ρ_object > ρ_fluid), and calculating submerged fractions.
example_tasks: An iceberg (density 917 kg/m³) floats in seawater (density 1025 kg/m³). What fraction of the iceberg is submerged?
Explain why a steel ship floats but a solid steel ball of the same mass sinks.
A wooden block (density 600 kg/m³) floats in water. Calculate what percentage of its volume is above water.

sub_topics.name: Apparent Weight in Fluids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that objects in fluids have apparent weight equal to true weight minus buoyant force.
example_tasks: A 5 kg rock weighs 40 N when submerged in water. Calculate the buoyant force and the rock's volume.
Explain why objects feel lighter when submerged in water, using the concept of apparent weight.
A person weighs 700 N in air and 70 N when fully submerged in water. Calculate the person's volume and density.

sub_topics.name: Applications of Buoyancy
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing buoyancy in submarines, hot air balloons, hydrometers, and other applications.
example_tasks: Explain how submarines control depth by varying buoyancy through adjusting water in ballast tanks.
Describe how hot air balloons work: heated air inside is less dense than surrounding air, creating a net upward buoyant force.
A hydrometer measures liquid density by the depth to which it sinks. Explain the principle and how to read one.

sub_topics.name: Fluid Dynamics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding fluid flow, ideal fluid assumptions, continuity equation relating flow speed and cross-sectional area.

sub_topics.name: Ideal Fluid Assumptions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding idealized assumptions: incompressible, non-viscous (no internal friction), steady flow, and irrotational (no turbulence).
example_tasks: List and explain the four assumptions for an ideal fluid: incompressible, non-viscous, steady flow, irrotational.
Explain why water is a better approximation to an ideal fluid than honey or air.
Discuss which ideal fluid assumptions are reasonable for (a) water flowing through a pipe and (b) air flowing over a wing.

sub_topics.name: Continuity Equation
sub_topics.short_description: Applying the continuity equation A₁v₁ = A₂v₂ for incompressible fluid flow, showing that flow speed increases when area decreases.
example_tasks: Water flows through a pipe that narrows from 0.1 m² to 0.02 m² cross-section. If the speed in the wide section is 2 m/s, find the speed in the narrow section.
Explain why water flows faster from a garden hose when you partially cover the opening with your thumb.
Blood flows through an artery that branches into many capillaries. If the total capillary area is 1000 times the artery area, how do the speeds compare?

sub_topics.name: Volume Flow Rate
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating volume flow rate Q = Av (volume per time) and understanding its conservation in steady flow.
example_tasks: Water flows through a 0.05 m² pipe at 3 m/s. Calculate the volume flow rate in m³/s and in liters per minute.
A river has cross-sectional area 50 m² and flows at 0.5 m/s. Calculate the volume of water passing per minute.
Show that conservation of mass for an incompressible fluid leads to the continuity equation: if Q is constant, then A₁v₁ = A₂v₂.

sub_topics.name: Bernoulli's Equation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding and applying Bernoulli's equation as conservation of energy for flowing fluids, relating pressure, speed, and height.

sub_topics.name: Bernoulli's Principle
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that in flowing fluid, pressure decreases when flow speed increases, as a consequence of energy conservation.
example_tasks: Explain qualitatively why a shower curtain is pulled inward when water flows: fast-moving air inside has lower pressure.
Describe how airplane wings generate lift using Bernoulli's principle: air moves faster over curved top surface, creating lower pressure.
Explain why a spinning baseball curves (Magnus effect) using Bernoulli's principle and differential air speeds.

sub_topics.name: Bernoulli's Equation Formula
sub_topics.short_description: Applying P + ½ρv² + ρgh = constant along a streamline to solve fluid dynamics problems.
example_tasks: Water flows through a horizontal pipe from a wide section (area 0.1 m², pressure 200 kPa, speed 1 m/s) to a narrow section (area 0.05 m²). Calculate pressure in the narrow section.
A water tank has a small hole at depth 5 m below the surface. Use Bernoulli's equation to calculate the speed of water exiting the hole (Torricelli's theorem).
Explain each term in Bernoulli's equation: P (pressure energy per volume), ½ρv² (kinetic energy per volume), ρgh (potential energy per volume).

sub_topics.name: Applications of Bernoulli's Equation
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing practical applications including airfoils, venturi meters, atomizers, and flow through orifices.
example_tasks: Describe how a venturi meter measures flow speed by comparing pressure in wide and narrow sections of a pipe.
Explain how a perfume atomizer works: fast air flow over tube opening creates low pressure, drawing liquid up.
Analyze a siphon using Bernoulli's equation, explaining how liquid can flow over a barrier higher than its source.

sub_topics.name: Viscosity and Turbulence (Introduction)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding viscosity as internal friction in fluids, Reynolds number, and transition from laminar to turbulent flow.

sub_topics.name: Viscosity Concept
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding viscosity as resistance to flow, with high viscosity fluids (honey) flowing slower than low viscosity fluids (water).
example_tasks: Compare the viscosities of water, motor oil, and honey. Explain why honey flows much more slowly.
Explain how temperature affects viscosity: most liquids become less viscous when heated (exception: gases become more viscous).
Describe applications where high viscosity is desired (shock absorbers, lubricants) and where low viscosity is better (fuel lines).

sub_topics.name: Laminar and Turbulent Flow
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between smooth laminar flow (streamlines) and chaotic turbulent flow (eddies and vortices).
example_tasks: Describe the difference between laminar flow (smooth, predictable) and turbulent flow (chaotic, mixing).
Explain why smoke from a cigarette rises smoothly (laminar) at first, then becomes chaotic (turbulent) higher up.
Give examples of laminar flow (blood in capillaries, oil in narrow tubes) and turbulent flow (rapids in rivers, air behind blunt objects).

sub_topics.name: Reynolds Number (Introduction)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Reynolds number as a dimensionless parameter predicting transition from laminar to turbulent flow.
example_tasks: Explain that Reynolds number Re = ρvL/η depends on density, speed, characteristic length, and viscosity.
Describe the general rule: low Re (< 2000) typically means laminar flow, high Re (> 4000) typically means turbulent flow.
Explain why small objects moving slowly in viscous fluids (like bacteria in water) experience laminar flow despite similar geometry to larger faster objects.

name: Thermodynamics and Gas Laws
short_description: Advanced study of thermodynamics including ideal gas law, kinetic molecular theory, laws of thermodynamics, heat engines, entropy, and thermodynamic processes. Students develop quantitative skills in thermal physics.

sub_topics.name: Ideal Gas Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding and applying the ideal gas law PV = nRT, relating pressure, volume, temperature, and amount of gas.

sub_topics.name: Ideal Gas Equation
sub_topics.short_description: Using PV = nRT where R = 8.314 J/(mol·K) is the universal gas constant, with temperature in kelvins.
example_tasks: A gas occupies 0.5 m³ at pressure 200 kPa and temperature 300 K. Calculate the number of moles of gas (R = 8.314 J/(mol·K)).
A balloon contains 2 moles of helium at 25°C and 101 kPa. Calculate the volume of the balloon.
Rearrange PV = nRT to solve for each variable, and explain the physical meaning of each quantity.

sub_topics.name: Special Gas Processes
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing isothermal (constant T), isobaric (constant P), isochoric (constant V), and adiabatic (no heat transfer) processes.
example_tasks: For an isothermal process, show that PV = constant. If a gas expands isothermally from 1 L at 300 kPa to 3 L, find the final pressure.
In an isobaric process, a gas expands from 2 L to 5 L at constant pressure 100 kPa. Calculate the work done by the gas.
Describe what happens to P, V, and T during: (a) isothermal compression, (b) isobaric expansion, (c) isochoric heating.

sub_topics.name: Gas Law Calculations
sub_topics.short_description: Solving combined gas law problems and converting between moles, mass, and number of molecules.
example_tasks: A gas at 300 K and 2 atm occupies 10 L. If heated to 600 K at constant volume, what is the final pressure?
Calculate the number of molecules in 0.5 moles of gas using Avogadro's number (N_A = 6.02 × 10²³ mol⁻¹).
A tire contains air at 250 kPa and 20°C. After driving, the temperature increases to 50°C. Calculate the new pressure assuming constant volume.

sub_topics.name: Kinetic Molecular Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the microscopic basis of gas behavior, relating macroscopic properties to molecular motion and energy.

sub_topics.name: Assumptions of Kinetic Molecular Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the model assumptions: point particles, elastic collisions, negligible intermolecular forces, random motion.
example_tasks: List the five main assumptions of kinetic molecular theory for ideal gases.
Explain why real gases deviate from ideal behavior at high pressure and low temperature.
Discuss which gases behave most ideally: small molecules like helium or large molecules like octane? Explain.

sub_topics.name: Molecular Speeds and Temperature
sub_topics.short_description: Relating temperature to average kinetic energy: KE_avg = (3/2)kT, and calculating root-mean-square speed.
example_tasks: Calculate the average kinetic energy of a gas molecule at 300 K (k = 1.38 × 10⁻²³ J/K).
Derive that root-mean-square speed v_rms = √(3kT/m) = √(3RT/M) for gas molecules.
Calculate the rms speed of oxygen molecules (M = 32 g/mol) at room temperature (300 K).

sub_topics.name: Pressure from Molecular Collisions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that gas pressure results from countless molecular collisions with container walls.
example_tasks: Explain how increasing temperature increases pressure at constant volume, using kinetic molecular theory.
Describe why pressure increases when volume decreases at constant temperature in terms of collision frequency.
Qualitatively explain how kinetic theory leads to the ideal gas law PV = NkT where N is the number of molecules.

sub_topics.name: Distribution of Molecular Speeds
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that molecules have a distribution of speeds (Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution), not all at the same speed.
example_tasks: Sketch a Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution curve showing most probable speed, average speed, and rms speed.
Explain how the speed distribution changes with temperature: higher temperature means broader distribution and higher average speed.
Describe why some molecules can escape Earth's atmosphere: those with speeds above escape velocity in the high-speed tail of the distribution.

sub_topics.name: First Law of Thermodynamics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding and applying the first law ΔU = Q - W, analyzing heat, work, and internal energy changes in thermodynamic processes.

sub_topics.name: Statement of First Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding ΔU = Q - W: change in internal energy equals heat added minus work done by the system (energy conservation).
example_tasks: A gas absorbs 500 J of heat and does 300 J of work. Calculate the change in internal energy.
Explain the sign conventions: Q positive when heat enters system, W positive when system does work (expansion).
Show that the first law of thermodynamics is a statement of energy conservation applied to thermal systems.

sub_topics.name: Work in Thermodynamic Processes
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating work done by gas during expansion/compression using W = ∫PdV, interpreting as area under PV curve.
example_tasks: A gas expands at constant pressure 200 kPa from volume 2 L to 5 L. Calculate the work done by the gas.
Explain why work is the area under the curve on a PV diagram for any thermodynamic process.
Compare the work done in isothermal versus adiabatic expansion from the same initial state to the same final volume.

sub_topics.name: Applying First Law to Processes
sub_topics.short_description: Using the first law to analyze isothermal, adiabatic, isobaric, and isochoric processes.
example_tasks: For an isothermal process (ΔT = 0), show that ΔU = 0, therefore Q = W (all heat goes into work).
For an isochoric process (ΔV = 0), show that W = 0, therefore ΔU = Q (all heat increases internal energy).
In an adiabatic process (Q = 0), show that ΔU = -W. If gas does work expanding, its internal energy and temperature decrease.

sub_topics.name: Internal Energy and Temperature
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that for an ideal gas, internal energy depends only on temperature: ΔU = nC_v ΔT.
example_tasks: Calculate the change in internal energy when 2 moles of ideal gas are heated from 300 K to 400 K (use appropriate molar heat capacity).
Explain why internal energy of an ideal gas depends only on temperature, not on pressure or volume.
Show that in an isothermal process for an ideal gas, ΔU = 0 because temperature doesn't change.

sub_topics.name: Second Law of Thermodynamics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding entropy, the second law, heat engines, refrigerators, and the direction of thermodynamic processes.

sub_topics.name: Statements of Second Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding equivalent statements: entropy increases in isolated systems; heat flows from hot to cold; no perfect heat engine exists.
example_tasks: Explain the Kelvin-Planck statement: no engine can convert heat completely into work in a cyclic process.
Explain the Clausius statement: heat cannot spontaneously flow from cold to hot without external work.
Give everyday examples illustrating the second law: ice melting in warm water, mixing hot and cold water, diffusion of perfume.

sub_topics.name: Heat Engines
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding heat engines that convert heat to work, calculating efficiency η = W/Q_h = 1 - Q_c/Q_h.
example_tasks: A heat engine absorbs 1000 J from a hot reservoir and exhausts 600 J to a cold reservoir. Calculate (a) work output and (b) efficiency.
Explain why no real heat engine can have 100% efficiency: some heat must be exhausted to the cold reservoir.
Calculate the work done per cycle by a heat engine with 30% efficiency that absorbs 5000 J from the hot reservoir.

sub_topics.name: Carnot Engine
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the Carnot cycle as the most efficient possible heat engine, with efficiency η_Carnot = 1 - T_c/T_h.
example_tasks: Calculate the maximum possible efficiency of a heat engine operating between reservoirs at 600 K and 300 K.
Explain why the Carnot efficiency depends only on the temperatures of the hot and cold reservoirs.
A Carnot engine operates with 40% efficiency. If the cold reservoir is at 300 K, calculate the hot reservoir temperature.

sub_topics.name: Refrigerators and Heat Pumps
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding refrigerators as reverse heat engines, using work to transfer heat from cold to hot, with coefficient of performance.
example_tasks: Explain how a refrigerator works: work input moves heat from cold interior to warm exterior (opposite of heat engine).
A refrigerator removes 400 J from its interior and requires 100 J of work. Calculate (a) heat exhausted to room and (b) coefficient of performance.
Compare the energy efficiency of a heat pump for home heating versus electric resistance heating.

sub_topics.name: Entropy Concept
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding entropy as a measure of disorder or randomness, always increasing in isolated systems.
example_tasks: Explain qualitatively why entropy increases when ice melts: molecules go from ordered solid to disordered liquid.
Describe why breaking an egg increases entropy, and why we never see the reverse process spontaneously occur.
Explain how the second law relates to the arrow of time: entropy increase defines the forward direction of time.

sub_topics.name: Thermodynamic Processes and Diagrams
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing and sketching thermodynamic cycles on PV diagrams, calculating work and efficiency for various cycles.

sub_topics.name: PV Diagrams
sub_topics.short_description: Representing thermodynamic processes on pressure-volume diagrams, interpreting work as area under curves.
example_tasks: Sketch a PV diagram for an isothermal expansion, an isobaric compression, and an isochoric heating process.
On a PV diagram, explain why the area enclosed by a cycle equals the net work done per cycle.
Compare the work done in two different paths connecting the same initial and final states on a PV diagram.

sub_topics.name: Cyclic Processes
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing complete thermodynamic cycles where the system returns to its initial state, with ΔU_cycle = 0.
example_tasks: For a complete cycle, explain why ΔU = 0 and therefore Q_net = W_net.
A gas undergoes a cycle with Q_h = 800 J absorbed and Q_c = 500 J exhausted. Calculate the net work done.
Sketch a rectangular cycle on a PV diagram and calculate the net work as the area of the rectangle.

sub_topics.name: Carnot Cycle Diagram
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the four stages of the Carnot cycle: isothermal expansion, adiabatic expansion, isothermal compression, adiabatic compression.
example_tasks: Sketch the Carnot cycle on a PV diagram, labeling the four processes and indicating where heat is absorbed and rejected.
Describe what happens during each step of the Carnot cycle in terms of temperature, pressure, volume, heat, and work.
Explain why the Carnot cycle is reversible and therefore represents the maximum efficiency possible.

sub_topics.name: Otto and Diesel Cycles (Introduction)
sub_topics.short_description: Brief introduction to practical engine cycles used in automobiles, comparing to Carnot cycle.
example_tasks: Describe the basic steps of the Otto cycle (gasoline engine): intake, compression, combustion, exhaust.
Explain why real engines (Otto, Diesel) are less efficient than the Carnot efficiency due to irreversibilities.
Compare the compression ratios in Otto versus Diesel cycles and their effects on efficiency.

name: Wave Optics and Interference
short_description: Understanding the wave nature of light through interference, diffraction, and polarization phenomena. Students learn to analyze double-slit experiments, single-slit diffraction, diffraction gratings, and polarization of light.

sub_topics.name: Interference of Light
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding constructive and destructive interference of light waves, conditions for interference, and coherent sources.

sub_topics.name: Coherence and Interference
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that observable interference requires coherent sources with constant phase relationship.
example_tasks: Explain why two separate light bulbs don't produce an interference pattern: they are incoherent (random phase relationship).
Describe how a single light source can be split to create two coherent sources for interference experiments.
Define temporal coherence (wave train length) and spatial coherence (phase correlation across wavefront).

sub_topics.name: Path Difference and Interference
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that constructive interference occurs when path difference is integer wavelengths (mλ) and destructive when half-integer wavelengths ((m+½)λ).
example_tasks: Two coherent sources emit light with wavelength 600 nm. If the path difference to a point is 1200 nm, what type of interference occurs?
Explain why constructive interference requires path difference Δ = mλ where m = 0, 1, 2, ... (integer).
Calculate the path difference required for the 3rd order destructive interference of light with wavelength 500 nm.

sub_topics.name: Phase Difference and Interference
sub_topics.short_description: Relating path difference to phase difference using Δφ = (2π/λ)Δx, understanding interference in terms of phase.
example_tasks: If two waves have a path difference of λ/4, calculate the phase difference in radians and degrees.
Show that destructive interference corresponds to phase difference of π, 3π, 5π, ... (odd multiples of π).
Two waves interfere with phase difference 2π. Describe the resulting amplitude and explain why this is constructive interference.

sub_topics.name: Double-Slit Interference
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing Young's double-slit experiment, calculating fringe positions, and understanding the interference pattern.

sub_topics.name: Young's Double-Slit Experiment
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the classic experiment demonstrating wave nature of light through interference fringes.
example_tasks: Describe Young's double-slit experiment: light passes through two narrow slits and creates an interference pattern of bright and dark fringes on a screen.
Explain how the double-slit experiment provides evidence for the wave nature of light.
Sketch the interference pattern showing central bright fringe and alternating bright and dark fringes.

sub_topics.name: Bright Fringe Positions
sub_topics.short_description: Using d sin θ = mλ (for small angles: x = mλL/d) to calculate positions of bright fringes.
example_tasks: Light with wavelength 500 nm passes through slits separated by 0.1 mm, and the screen is 2 m away. Calculate the distance from center to the 1st bright fringe.
Derive the condition for bright fringes: path difference d sin θ = mλ where m = 0, ±1, ±2, ...
If the slit separation is doubled while keeping wavelength and screen distance constant, what happens to the fringe spacing?

sub_topics.name: Dark Fringe Positions
sub_topics.short_description: Using d sin θ = (m+½)λ to calculate positions of dark fringes (destructive interference).
example_tasks: For the same setup as previous problem (λ = 500 nm, d = 0.1 mm, L = 2 m), calculate the position of the 1st dark fringe.
Explain why dark fringes occur at path differences of λ/2, 3λ/2, 5λ/2, ...
Calculate the distance between adjacent bright fringes (fringe separation) using Δx = λL/d.

sub_topics.name: Effect of Parameters on Interference Pattern
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how changing wavelength, slit separation, and screen distance affects the interference pattern.
example_tasks: Describe how the fringe spacing changes when: (a) wavelength increases, (b) slit separation increases, (c) screen distance increases.
Red light (λ = 700 nm) and blue light (λ = 450 nm) are used in separate double-slit experiments with identical setups. Which produces wider fringe spacing?
Explain why white light produces colored fringes in a double-slit experiment (except at the central maximum).

sub_topics.name: Single-Slit Diffraction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding diffraction through a single slit, analyzing the diffraction pattern with central maximum and secondary maxima.

sub_topics.name: Single-Slit Diffraction Pattern
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that a single slit produces a central bright maximum with diminishing secondary maxima on either side.
example_tasks: Describe the single-slit diffraction pattern: wide central maximum, narrower secondary maxima separated by dark fringes.
Explain why the central maximum in single-slit diffraction is twice as wide as the secondary maxima.
Compare single-slit diffraction pattern to double-slit interference pattern in terms of fringe widths and intensities.

sub_topics.name: Dark Fringe Minima in Single-Slit Diffraction
sub_topics.short_description: Using a sin θ = mλ (m = ±1, ±2, ...) to locate dark fringes, where a is slit width.
example_tasks: Light with wavelength 600 nm passes through a single slit of width 0.2 mm. Calculate the angle to the 1st dark fringe.
Derive the condition for dark fringes: slit width times sin θ equals integer wavelengths (a sin θ = mλ).
A single slit of width 0.1 mm produces a diffraction pattern on a screen 3 m away. If the 1st dark fringe is at 1.8 cm, calculate the wavelength.

sub_topics.name: Central Maximum Width
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating the width of the central maximum, which extends from m = -1 to m = +1 dark fringes.
example_tasks: Calculate the width of the central maximum for light of wavelength 500 nm through a 0.15 mm slit, with screen at 2 m distance.
Explain why decreasing the slit width causes the central maximum to widen (more spreading).
Show that the angular width of the central maximum is approximately 2λ/a for small angles.

sub_topics.name: Combined Double-Slit Interference and Single-Slit Diffraction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that real double-slit patterns are modulated by single-slit diffraction envelope.
example_tasks: Explain why some interference fringes are missing in a real double-slit experiment: single-slit diffraction minima coincide with certain interference maxima.
Sketch a realistic double-slit pattern showing narrow interference fringes within a wider single-slit diffraction envelope.
If slit width a equals half the slit separation d, which interference orders are missing from the pattern?

sub_topics.name: Diffraction Gratings
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding diffraction gratings with many slits, analyzing sharp interference maxima, and applications in spectroscopy.

sub_topics.name: Grating Equation
sub_topics.short_description: Using d sin θ = mλ for gratings where d is the spacing between adjacent slits, producing sharp maxima.
example_tasks: A diffraction grating has 5000 lines per cm. Calculate the grating spacing d.
Light with wavelength 550 nm strikes a grating with d = 2 μm. Calculate the angle to the 1st order maximum (m = 1).
Explain why diffraction grating maxima are much sharper than double-slit fringes: more slits create more interference.

sub_topics.name: Multiple Orders and Missing Orders
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing different orders (m = 0, ±1, ±2, ...) and understanding when certain orders are missing.
example_tasks: For a grating with d = 1.5 μm and light of wavelength 600 nm, calculate angles for the 0th, 1st, and 2nd order maxima.
Explain why there's a maximum order number: when sin θ would exceed 1, that order doesn't exist.
Calculate the highest order visible for 500 nm light with a grating of spacing 2 μm.

sub_topics.name: Resolving Power of Gratings
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that gratings can separate closely spaced wavelengths, with resolving power R = mN where N is number of lines.
example_tasks: Explain why diffraction gratings are used in spectrometers: they separate different wavelengths into distinct angles.
A grating has 10,000 lines. Calculate its resolving power in the 2nd order (m = 2).
Describe how increasing the number of grating lines improves spectral resolution (ability to distinguish close wavelengths).

sub_topics.name: Applications of Diffraction Gratings
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing uses in spectroscopy, wavelength measurement, and optical instruments.
example_tasks: Explain how astronomers use gratings to analyze starlight and determine stellar composition.
Describe how a grating spectrometer works: light is dispersed by angle according to wavelength.
Compare diffraction gratings to prisms for separating colors: gratings have linear dispersion, prisms have nonlinear dispersion.

sub_topics.name: Thin Film Interference
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding interference in thin films due to reflections from top and bottom surfaces, analyzing conditions for constructive and destructive interference.

sub_topics.name: Interference in Thin Films
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that light reflected from top and bottom surfaces of a film interferes, creating colored patterns.
example_tasks: Explain why soap bubbles and oil slicks show rainbow colors: thin film interference separates wavelengths.
Describe the two reflected rays that interfere: one from the top surface and one from the bottom surface of the film.
Explain why thin film colors change with viewing angle: path difference changes with angle.

sub_topics.name: Phase Change on Reflection
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that reflection from a denser medium causes 180° (π) phase change, while reflection from less dense medium causes no phase change.
example_tasks: Explain the phase change rule: light reflecting from higher index material undergoes 180° phase shift.
For an air-film-glass system, identify which reflection (top or bottom surface) undergoes phase change.
A soap film (n = 1.33) in air: which surface reflection has a phase change?

sub_topics.name: Thin Film Interference Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Using 2nt = mλ or 2nt = (m+½)λ depending on phase changes, where t is film thickness and n is refractive index.
example_tasks: Derive the condition for constructive interference in a thin film considering path difference and phase changes.
An oil film (n = 1.5) on water (n = 1.33) appears bright for 600 nm light at normal incidence. Calculate the minimum film thickness.
For an air wedge between two glass plates, explain why alternating bright and dark fringes appear.

sub_topics.name: Applications of Thin Film Interference
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing anti-reflection coatings, enhancing reflection, and testing optical surfaces.
example_tasks: Explain how anti-reflection coatings on eyeglasses work: film thickness chosen so reflected waves destructively interfere.
Calculate the thickness of MgF₂ coating (n = 1.38) needed to minimize reflection of 550 nm light from glass (n = 1.5).
Describe Newton's rings: circular interference pattern formed between a curved surface and flat surface.

sub_topics.name: Polarization of Light
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding polarization as the orientation of light's electric field oscillations, analyzing polarizers and applications.

sub_topics.name: Nature of Polarization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that light is a transverse wave with electric field perpendicular to propagation direction, which can be polarized.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between unpolarized light (random orientations) and polarized light (single orientation).
Describe why polarization demonstrates that light is a transverse wave, not longitudinal.
Give examples of polarized light: reflected light, light from LCD screens, light through Polaroid filters.

sub_topics.name: Polarizers and Malus's Law
sub_topics.short_description: Using Malus's law I = I₀ cos²θ to calculate transmitted intensity through polarizers at angle θ.
example_tasks: Unpolarized light with intensity I₀ passes through a polarizer. What is the transmitted intensity? (Answer: I₀/2)
Polarized light passes through a second polarizer at 30° to the first. If incident intensity is 100 W/m², calculate transmitted intensity using Malus's law.
Two polarizers are crossed (90° angle). Explain why no light is transmitted through this combination.

sub_topics.name: Polarization by Reflection
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that reflected light is partially polarized, completely polarized at Brewster's angle where tan θ_B = n₂/n₁.
example_tasks: Explain why light reflected from water or glass is partially polarized parallel to the surface.
Calculate Brewster's angle for light reflecting from water (n = 1.33) from air (n = 1.0).
Describe how polarizing sunglasses reduce glare: they block horizontally polarized light reflected from horizontal surfaces.

sub_topics.name: Applications of Polarization
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing uses in sunglasses, LCD displays, optical stress analysis, and 3D movies.
example_tasks: Explain how LCD displays work: liquid crystals rotate polarization, controlled by electric fields to create images.
Describe polarizing filters in photography: reducing glare and increasing contrast in sky and water scenes.
Explain how 3D movies use polarization: left and right eye images are polarized differently, separated by polarizing glasses.

name: Electrostatics and Electric Fields (Advanced)
short_description: Advanced study of electric fields, Gauss's law, electric potential, capacitance, and energy storage in electric fields. Students develop sophisticated analytical skills in electrostatics.

sub_topics.name: Electric Flux and Gauss's Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding electric flux through surfaces and applying Gauss's law to calculate electric fields for symmetric charge distributions.

sub_topics.name: Electric Flux Concept
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding electric flux Φ_E = E·A = EA cos θ as a measure of electric field passing through a surface.
example_tasks: Calculate the electric flux through a 0.5 m² surface if the electric field is 1000 N/C perpendicular to the surface.
A uniform electric field of 500 N/C makes an angle of 60° with a 2 m² surface. Calculate the electric flux.
Explain the units of electric flux: N·m²/C, which is equivalent to V·m.

sub_topics.name: Gauss's Law Statement
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Gauss's law: electric flux through a closed surface equals enclosed charge divided by ε₀ (Φ_E = Q_enclosed/ε₀).
example_tasks: State Gauss's law in words and mathematical form, explaining each term.
A closed surface encloses a charge of +5 μC. Calculate the total electric flux through the surface (ε₀ = 8.85 × 10⁻¹² C²/(N·m²)).
Explain why Gauss's law is particularly useful for calculating electric fields when symmetry is present.

sub_topics.name: Applying Gauss's Law with Symmetry
sub_topics.short_description: Using Gauss's law to find electric fields for spherical, cylindrical, and planar symmetry.
example_tasks: Use Gauss's law to derive the electric field at distance r from a point charge Q, showing E = kQ/r².
Apply Gauss's law to find the electric field outside a uniformly charged sphere of radius R with total charge Q.
Explain why Gauss's law is difficult to apply without symmetry: the integral ∮E·dA cannot be easily evaluated.

sub_topics.name: Electric Field Inside and Outside Conductors
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that electric field inside a conductor is zero and charge resides on the surface.
example_tasks: Explain why the electric field inside a conductor in electrostatic equilibrium must be zero.
Use Gauss's law to show that excess charge on a conductor resides entirely on its surface.
A hollow conducting sphere has charge Q. Find the electric field (a) inside the cavity, (b) in the conductor, (c) outside the sphere.

sub_topics.name: Electric Potential (Advanced)
sub_topics.short_description: Advanced analysis of electric potential, equipotential surfaces, calculating potential for charge distributions, and relating potential to field.

sub_topics.name: Electric Potential of Point Charges
sub_topics.short_description: Using V = kQ/r for point charges and V = Σ(kQ_i/r_i) for multiple charges, understanding potential is a scalar.
example_tasks: Calculate the electric potential at a point 0.5 m from a +3 μC charge.
Three charges (+2 μC, -4 μC, +3 μC) are located at the corners of an equilateral triangle with side 0.1 m. Calculate the potential at the center.
Explain why electric potential is easier to calculate than electric field for multiple charges: potential is scalar, not vector.

sub_topics.name: Potential Difference and Work
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that work to move charge q through potential difference ΔV is W = qΔV, with energy conservation.
example_tasks: Calculate the work required to move a +5 μC charge from a point at 100 V to a point at 400 V.
An electron (q = -1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C) moves through a potential difference of 1000 V. Calculate the change in its kinetic energy.
Explain why positive charges naturally move from high to low potential while negative charges move from low to high potential.

sub_topics.name: Equipotential Surfaces (Advanced)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding properties of equipotential surfaces: perpendicular to field lines, no work to move along them.
example_tasks: Sketch equipotential surfaces around: (a) a positive point charge, (b) two equal positive charges, (c) parallel plates.
Explain why electric field lines are always perpendicular to equipotential surfaces.
Calculate the spacing between equipotential surfaces for a uniform field of 100 N/C if surfaces differ by 10 V.

sub_topics.name: Relationship Between Field and Potential
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that electric field is negative gradient of potential: E = -dV/dx (one dimension) or E = -∇V (three dimensions).
example_tasks: If the potential varies as V(x) = 100 - 50x (V in volts, x in meters), calculate the electric field.
Explain the negative sign in E = -dV/dx: field points in direction of decreasing potential.
Given equipotential lines on a diagram, sketch the electric field lines showing they point from high to low potential, perpendicular to equipotentials.

sub_topics.name: Capacitance and Capacitors
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding capacitance, calculating capacitance for various geometries, energy storage in capacitors, and capacitor combinations.

sub_topics.name: Defining Capacitance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding capacitance as C = Q/V, measured in farads (F), representing charge stored per volt.
example_tasks: A capacitor stores 60 μC of charge when connected to a 12 V battery. Calculate its capacitance.
Explain the physical meaning of capacitance: ability to store charge per unit voltage.
Convert 1000 μF (microfarads) to farads, millifarads, nanofarads, and picofarads.

sub_topics.name: Parallel Plate Capacitor
sub_topics.short_description: Using C = ε₀A/d for parallel plates, understanding dependence on area, separation, and dielectric.
example_tasks: Calculate the capacitance of parallel plates with area 0.01 m² separated by 1 mm in vacuum (ε₀ = 8.85 × 10⁻¹² F/m).
Explain why increasing plate area increases capacitance while increasing separation decreases it.
If the plate separation is doubled, by what factor does the capacitance change?

sub_topics.name: Energy Stored in Capacitors
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating energy using U = ½QV = ½CV² = Q²/(2C), understanding energy density in electric field.
example_tasks: A 100 μF capacitor is charged to 50 V. Calculate the energy stored.
Derive the three equivalent expressions for energy stored in a capacitor starting from U = ½QV.
A capacitor stores 0.5 J when charged to 1000 V. Calculate its capacitance.

sub_topics.name: Dielectrics in Capacitors
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that inserting dielectric material increases capacitance by factor κ (dielectric constant): C = κC₀.
example_tasks: A capacitor has capacitance 10 μF with air between plates. Calculate the new capacitance when filled with material having κ = 5.
Explain how dielectric materials increase capacitance: they reduce the electric field, allowing more charge storage at same voltage.
Compare the energy stored in a capacitor with and without dielectric (a) at constant voltage and (b) at constant charge.

sub_topics.name: Capacitors in Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing series and parallel combinations of capacitors, and understanding capacitor charging and discharging.

sub_topics.name: Capacitors in Series
sub_topics.short_description: Using 1/C_eq = 1/C₁ + 1/C₂ + ... for series capacitors, understanding that series combination decreases total capacitance.
example_tasks: Three capacitors (2 μF, 3 μF, 6 μF) are connected in series. Calculate the equivalent capacitance.
Explain why capacitors in series have the same charge but different voltages across them.
Two identical capacitors in series have equivalent capacitance 5 μF. What is the capacitance of each?

sub_topics.name: Capacitors in Parallel
sub_topics.short_description: Using C_eq = C₁ + C₂ + ... for parallel capacitors, understanding that parallel combination increases total capacitance.
example_tasks: Three capacitors (4 μF, 6 μF, 10 μF) are connected in parallel. Calculate the equivalent capacitance.
Explain why capacitors in parallel have the same voltage but different charges.
Calculate the charge on each of three parallel capacitors (2 μF, 3 μF, 5 μF) connected to a 12 V battery.

sub_topics.name: Complex Capacitor Combinations
sub_topics.short_description: Solving circuits with both series and parallel capacitor combinations.
example_tasks: Three capacitors are arranged: C₁ = 6 μF in series with a parallel combination of C₂ = 4 μF and C₃ = 8 μF. Find equivalent capacitance.
A circuit has 20 V across a combination of capacitors. Calculate the voltage across and charge on each capacitor.
Explain the step-by-step method for reducing complex capacitor networks to a single equivalent capacitance.

sub_topics.name: RC Circuits (Introduction)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding charging and discharging of capacitors through resistors, introducing time constant τ = RC.
example_tasks: Define the time constant for an RC circuit: τ = RC, which determines how quickly the capacitor charges or discharges.
A 100 μF capacitor charges through a 10 kΩ resistor. Calculate the time constant.
Qualitatively describe the exponential nature of capacitor charging: voltage approaches maximum asymptotically with time constant τ.

name: DC and AC Circuits (Advanced)
short_description: Advanced circuit analysis including Kirchhoff's laws applications, RC circuits, introduction to AC circuits, impedance, and power in AC circuits. Students develop sophisticated circuit analysis skills.

sub_topics.name: Advanced DC Circuit Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Using systematic methods to analyze multi-loop circuits with multiple voltage sources and resistors.

sub_topics.name: Multi-Loop Circuit Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Applying Kirchhoff's laws systematically to solve circuits with multiple loops and junctions.
example_tasks: Analyze a circuit with two batteries and three resistors arranged in two loops. Set up equations using Kirchhoff's laws and solve for all currents.
Describe the systematic approach: (1) label all currents, (2) apply junction rule, (3) apply loop rule to independent loops, (4) solve equations.
For a circuit with three loops, explain how to determine the number of independent equations needed (typically n-1 junctions, plus enough loops).

sub_topics.name: Thévenin and Norton Theorems (Introduction)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that complex circuits can be simplified to equivalent voltage source with series resistance (Thévenin) or current source with parallel resistance (Norton).
example_tasks: Explain Thévenin's theorem: any two-terminal linear circuit can be replaced by a voltage source V_th in series with resistance R_th.
Describe Norton's theorem: any two-terminal linear circuit can be replaced by a current source I_N in parallel with resistance R_N.
For a simple circuit, find the Thévenin equivalent voltage and resistance seen by a load resistor.

sub_topics.name: Maximum Power Transfer
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that maximum power is delivered to a load when load resistance equals source resistance.
example_tasks: Prove that maximum power transfer occurs when R_load = R_source for a circuit with voltage source and source resistance.
A battery with EMF 12 V and internal resistance 2 Ω is connected to a variable load. Calculate the load resistance for maximum power transfer and the maximum power.
Explain why power transmission uses high voltage: to minimize power loss in transmission lines, we want R_line << R_load, not matched.

sub_topics.name: RC Circuits and Transients
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing capacitor charging and discharging through resistors, understanding exponential behavior and time constants.

sub_topics.name: Charging a Capacitor
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding exponential charging: Q(t) = Q_max(1 - e^(-t/RC)), with voltage V_C(t) = V_0(1 - e^(-t/RC)).
example_tasks: A 50 μF capacitor charges through a 20 kΩ resistor from a 12 V battery. Write equations for charge and voltage as functions of time.
Calculate the voltage across a charging capacitor at t = τ, 2τ, and 5τ. Show that it reaches ~63%, ~86%, and ~99% of final voltage.
Sketch graphs of voltage across capacitor and voltage across resistor versus time during charging.

sub_topics.name: Discharging a Capacitor
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding exponential discharging: Q(t) = Q_0 e^(-t/RC), with voltage V_C(t) = V_0 e^(-t/RC).
example_tasks: A charged capacitor (100 V) discharges through a 10 kΩ resistor. If the time constant is 2 seconds, calculate the voltage after 2, 4, and 6 seconds.
Show that after one time constant, the voltage decreases to 1/e ≈ 37% of its initial value.
Calculate the energy dissipated in the resistor during the complete discharge of a capacitor initially charged to voltage V₀.

sub_topics.name: Applications of RC Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing practical applications including timing circuits, filters, and pacemakers.
example_tasks: Explain how RC circuits function as timing elements in electronic devices like camera flashes and windshield wiper controls.
Describe how a simple RC circuit can act as a low-pass filter: low frequencies pass, high frequencies are blocked.
Cardiac pacemakers use RC circuits to control timing. Explain how the time constant determines the heart rate.

sub_topics.name: Alternating Current Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding AC voltage and current, sinusoidal waveforms, frequency, RMS values, and power in AC circuits.

sub_topics.name: AC Voltage and Current
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding sinusoidal variation: V(t) = V_max sin(ωt) and I(t) = I_max sin(ωt - φ), with angular frequency ω = 2πf.
example_tasks: Write the equation for a 120 V AC source (RMS) at 60 Hz, expressing voltage as a function of time.
Explain the difference between instantaneous voltage V(t) and RMS (root-mean-square) voltage V_rms.
Calculate the angular frequency ω for household AC (60 Hz in US, 50 Hz in Europe).

sub_topics.name: RMS Values
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding RMS values: V_rms = V_max/√2 and I_rms = I_max/√2, representing equivalent DC values for power calculations.
example_tasks: An AC voltage has maximum value 170 V. Calculate the RMS voltage.
Explain why we use RMS values rather than peak values: RMS gives the equivalent DC value that would deliver the same average power.
A 120 V (RMS) household outlet has what peak voltage? What is the voltage at t = T/4 (quarter period)?

sub_topics.name: Power in AC Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating average power P_avg = V_rms I_rms cos φ, where φ is phase angle, and understanding power factor.
example_tasks: Calculate the average power dissipated in a resistor with R = 50 Ω connected to 120 V (RMS) AC source.
Explain the power factor cos φ: it represents the fraction of apparent power that does useful work (for pure resistor, φ = 0 and cos φ = 1).
An AC circuit has V_rms = 120 V, I_rms = 5 A, and power factor 0.8. Calculate the average power.

sub_topics.name: Purely Resistive AC Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that in pure resistance, voltage and current are in phase, with Ohm's law applying to RMS values.
example_tasks: A 100 Ω resistor is connected to 120 V (RMS) AC. Calculate the RMS current and average power.
Sketch voltage and current waveforms for a resistor in AC circuit, showing they are in phase.
Explain why average power in pure resistance is P = V_rms I_rms = I²_rms R = V²_rms/R, same form as DC.

sub_topics.name: Capacitors and Inductors in AC Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding capacitive and inductive reactance, phase relationships in AC, and introduction to impedance.

sub_topics.name: Capacitive Reactance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that capacitors impede AC with reactance X_C = 1/(ωC), with current leading voltage by 90°.
example_tasks: Calculate the capacitive reactance of a 10 μF capacitor at 60 Hz and at 1000 Hz. Explain why reactance decreases with frequency.
Explain why current leads voltage by 90° in a capacitor: capacitor voltage depends on accumulated charge.
A capacitor with reactance 100 Ω is connected to 50 V (RMS) AC. Calculate the RMS current.

sub_topics.name: Inductive Reactance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that inductors impede AC with reactance X_L = ωL, with voltage leading current by 90°.
example_tasks: Calculate the inductive reactance of a 0.5 H inductor at 60 Hz and at 1000 Hz. Explain why reactance increases with frequency.
Explain why voltage leads current by 90° in an inductor: back-EMF opposes current changes.
Compare the behavior of capacitors and inductors in AC: one passes high frequencies (C), one blocks high frequencies (L).

sub_topics.name: Impedance (Introduction)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding impedance Z as generalized resistance for AC circuits, combining resistance and reactance.
example_tasks: Define impedance as the ratio of voltage to current in AC circuits: Z = V_rms/I_rms.
For a series circuit with resistance R and capacitive reactance X_C, calculate impedance: Z = √(R² + X_C²).
Explain why impedance is measured in ohms but is not the same as resistance: it includes reactive effects.

sub_topics.name: RLC Series Circuits (Introduction)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding series combinations of resistors, capacitors, and inductors, with impedance Z = √(R² + (X_L - X_C)²).
example_tasks: A series circuit has R = 30 Ω, X_L = 40 Ω, X_C = 10 Ω. Calculate the impedance and phase angle.
Explain resonance in RLC circuits: when X_L = X_C, impedance is minimum (equals R) and current is maximum.
Describe the phase relationship between voltage and current in RLC circuits: voltage leads (inductive), lags (capacitive), or in phase (resonance).

sub_topics.name: Power in AC Circuits (Advanced)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding real power, reactive power, apparent power, and power factor correction in AC systems.

sub_topics.name: Real, Reactive, and Apparent Power
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between real power (P = V_rms I_rms cos φ), reactive power (Q = V_rms I_rms sin φ), and apparent power (S = V_rms I_rms).
example_tasks: Explain the difference: real power does work (watts), reactive power shuttles between source and load (VAR), apparent power is total (VA).
A motor draws 10 A at 120 V with power factor 0.6. Calculate real power, reactive power, and apparent power.
Show that S² = P² + Q², the relationship between apparent, real, and reactive power.

sub_topics.name: Power Factor
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding power factor as cos φ, the ratio of real power to apparent power, indicating circuit efficiency.
example_tasks: A circuit has power factor 0.7 lagging. If apparent power is 1000 VA, calculate the real power.
Explain why utilities charge industrial customers for low power factor: they must supply higher current for same real power.
Describe lagging power factor (inductive load) versus leading power factor (capacitive load).

sub_topics.name: Power Factor Correction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how capacitors can correct lagging power factor from inductive loads, improving efficiency.
example_tasks: Explain power factor correction: adding capacitors to cancel inductive reactance, bringing power factor closer to 1.
An inductive motor has power factor 0.6. Calculate the capacitance needed to correct power factor to 0.95 at 60 Hz.
Describe benefits of power factor correction: reduced current, smaller wire sizes, lower transmission losses, avoided utility penalties.

name: Magnetism and Electromagnetic Theory
short_description: Advanced study of magnetic fields from currents, Ampere's law, magnetic materials, electromagnetic waves, and Maxwell's equations. Students develop deep understanding of electromagnetism as a unified theory.

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Fields from Currents (Advanced)
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating magnetic fields using Biot-Savart law and Ampere's law for various current configurations.

sub_topics.name: Biot-Savart Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the Biot-Savart law for calculating magnetic field from current elements: dB = (μ₀/4π)(I dl × r̂)/r².
example_tasks: State the Biot-Savart law and explain each term: μ₀ (permeability of free space), I (current), dl (current element), r (distance).
Explain why the Biot-Savart law is analogous to Coulomb's law: both involve inverse-square relationships.
Use the Biot-Savart law to qualitatively explain the magnetic field pattern around a straight current-carrying wire.

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Field of a Straight Wire
sub_topics.short_description: Using B = μ₀I/(2πr) to calculate the magnetic field at distance r from a long straight wire carrying current I.
example_tasks: Calculate the magnetic field at 5 cm from a wire carrying 10 A (μ₀ = 4π × 10⁻⁷ T·m/A).
Show that the magnetic field decreases as 1/r with distance from a long straight wire.
Two parallel wires separated by 10 cm each carry 5 A in the same direction. Calculate the magnetic field midway between them.

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Field of a Circular Loop
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating the magnetic field at the center of a circular loop: B = μ₀I/(2R), and on the axis.
example_tasks: Calculate the magnetic field at the center of a circular loop of radius 0.1 m carrying current 2 A.
A coil with 50 turns and radius 5 cm carries 3 A. Calculate the magnetic field at its center.
Explain why the magnetic field at the center of a loop is stronger than on the axis away from the center.

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Field of a Solenoid
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that a solenoid produces uniform field inside: B = μ₀nI where n is turns per unit length.
example_tasks: A solenoid has 1000 turns over 0.5 m length and carries 2 A. Calculate the magnetic field inside.
Explain why the magnetic field inside a long solenoid is uniform and parallel to the axis.
Compare the field inside versus outside an ideal solenoid: inside is strong and uniform, outside is approximately zero.

sub_topics.name: Ampere's Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding and applying Ampere's law to calculate magnetic fields for symmetric current distributions.

sub_topics.name: Ampere's Law Statement
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Ampere's law: ∮B·dl = μ₀I_enclosed, the magnetic field analog of Gauss's law.
example_tasks: State Ampere's law in words and mathematical form: the line integral of magnetic field around a closed loop equals μ₀ times enclosed current.
Explain why Ampere's law is particularly useful when there is symmetry: cylindrical, planar, or toroidal.
A closed path encloses a wire carrying 5 A. Calculate the line integral ∮B·dl around this path.

sub_topics.name: Applying Ampere's Law
sub_topics.short_description: Using Ampere's law to derive magnetic fields for wires, solenoids, and toroids with appropriate symmetry.
